questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of two months of constipation. She has increased her water intake but has not tried over-the-counter medications. She is feeling more fatigued than usual. Past medical history includes bipolar disorder, for which she takes lithium. and high blood pressure, for which she takes lisinopril. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 122/82 mmHg.  Exam reveals a 10 lb weight gain from three months prior. The skin on the elbows and knees appears dry and flakey. Laboratory testing reveals a TSH of 9.1 mIU/L and serum-free T<sub>4</sub> of 0.71 ng/dL. Thyroid peroxidase antibodies and thyroglobulin antibodies are negative. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?

choices.text: Infiltration of brain tissue by granulomas

questions.solution:
This patient presents with constipation, fatigue, weight gain, an elevated TSH, and low serum free T4. These findings suggest a diagnosis of primary hypothyroidism. She does not have antithyroid antibodies, therefore Hashimoto thyroiditis, which is the most common cause of primary hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient parts of the world, can be ruled out. Other causes of hypothyroidism should be investigated. Patients presenting with primary hypothyroidism should have their medication lists reviewed for a cause of primary hypothyroidism. Lithium which is used to treat bipolar syndrome can cause hypothyroidism by inhibiting the uptake of iodine by the thyroid gland and interfering with secretion of thyroid hormones. Regular thyroid monitoring is recommended for patients taking lithium.

Typically, patients with hypothyroidism present nonspecific manifestations due to slowing of the metabolism like fatigue, constipation, weight gain, and depression. Other signs and symptoms include cold intolerance, skin dryness, brittle hair, bradycardia, and delayed relaxation of DTRs.  A goiter, or enlargement of the thyroid tissue may occur which can present as a palpable swelling over the anterior neck. Goiters can lead to compressive symptoms like difficulty swallowing, cough, or voice changes.

Medications that can cause hypothyroidism include lithium, amiodarone, immunotherapies, and antithyroid medicines. High TSH and a low serum-free T4 would be seen in laboratory studies in most cases of medication-induced hypothyroidism. Iatrogenic causes of hypothyroidism include external neck radiation, radioactive iodine treatment, and thyroid surgery. Iodine deficiency and excess can both cause primary hypothyroidism.  

Option Analysis

✅ Lithium use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Pituitary gland tumor:
Incorrect: A tumor in the pituitary gland can lead to central hypothyroidism. Patients with central hypothyroidism would have a low TSH and a low serum-free T4. Patients with pituitary tumors may also have deficiencies of other hormones such as ACTH, FSH, LH, GH, or prolactin, and may have localized symptoms such as headache or vision problems.  
❌ Autoimmune destruction of thyroid tissue:
Incorrect: Hypothyroidism caused by autoimmune destruction of thyroid tissue is consistent with Hashimoto thyroiditis. This patient has negative thyroid antibodies.
❌ Autoimmune destruction of blood vessels:
Incorrect:  Vasculitis is caused by autoimmune destruction of blood vessels.  Some patients with vasculitis have an increased risk of thyroid dysfunction, however, this patient has no signs or symptoms of systemic vasculitis.  
❌ Infiltration of brain tissue by granulomas:
Incorrect: Hypothalamo-pituitary sarcoidosis can lead to tertiary and secondary hypothyroidism respectively. Patients would have a low TSH and a low serum-free T4.  Patients with sarcoidosis may also present with signs and symptoms of sarcoidosis like shortness of breath, cough, and skin or nervous system manifestations.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents to the clinic with voice hoarseness, weight gain, and fatigue. She reports a weight gain of 11 kg (24 lb) during the past six months with no changes to her diet or activity level. She has no significant past medical history. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 43/min, and blood pressure is 115/95 mmHg. A palpable, smooth, rubbery, non-tender neck mass is noted on physical examination. The patient’s skin is dry, cold, and rough to the touch. Laboratory studies show a TSH of 11.1 mIU/L, a free T4 of 0.75 mIU/L, and the presence of anti-TPO and anti-Tg antibodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with compressive symptoms of a goiter (voice hoarseness), fatigue, and weight gain. She has an elevated TSH, low free T4, and the presence of antithyroid antibodies; therefore, can be diagnosed with Hashimoto thyroiditis.

Symptoms of Hashimoto thyroiditis include fatigue, weight gain, depression, dry skin, and cold intolerance. Physical examination findings consist of bradycardia, delayed relaxation of the deep tendon reflexes, peripheral edema, palpable (non-tender) smooth goiter, and diastolic hypertension. An elevated TSH, low free T4, and detection of autoantibodies (anti-TPO and anti-Tg) can be used to confirm the diagnosis of Hashimoto thyroiditis. The presence of either anti-TPO or anti-Tg antibodies is sufficient to make the diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hashimoto thyroiditis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hashitoxicosis:
Incorrect: Hashitoxicosis is a rare phase of hyperthyroidism that can occur during the initial stages of Hashimoto thyroiditis and results from the acute destruction of thyroid cells by autoantibodies. Patients will typically present with signs and symptoms associated with hyperthyroidism (eg, tachycardia, heat intolerance, weight loss, etc.) which is then followed by hypothyroidism.  
❌ Addison disease:
Incorrect: Addison disease typically presents with hyperpigmentation, weakness, fatigue, weight loss, salt craving, and orthostatic hypotension.  
❌ Nonthyroidal illness:
Incorrect: Patients recovering from a nonthyroidal illness can have transient elevations in TSH. This patient with anti-TPO and anti-Tg antibodies can be diagnosed with Hashimoto thyroiditis.  
❌ Graves disease:
Incorrect: Graves disease is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism and presents with tachycardia, palpitations, weight loss, hyperhidrosis, warm, moist skin, diarrhea, eye pain, and heat intolerance.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old woman with chronic kidney disease and type 2 diabetes mellitus presents to the clinic due to persistent fatigue. The patient mentions occasional bone pain and muscle weakness which she initially attributed to aging. She has attempted to stay active and has been trying to maintain a diet rich in calcium due to a family history of osteoporosis. On physical examination, the patient appears well-nourished with no significant abnormal findings. Laboratory studies are listed below. What is the most likely direct cause of this patient’s current condition?  

Laboratory study
Result
Serum calcium
8.1 mg/dL  
Serum phosphate  
5.2 mg/dL  
Glomerular filtration rate (GFR)  
19 mL/min/1.73 m2  
Parathyroid hormone (PTH)  
168 pg/mL
questions.solution:
This patient’s history, symptoms, (fatigue, bone pain, weakness) and laboratory values are consistent with secondary hyperparathyroidism. This patient has Stage 4 severe chronic kidney disease based on her glomerular filtration rate, causing chronic hypocalcemia leading to excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone. Chronic kidney disease is the most likely direct cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism in this patient.

Secondary hyperparathyroidism is a condition characterized by the excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands in response to chronic hypocalcemia. This is in contrast to primary hyperparathyroidism, where the excess PTH secretion is due to intrinsic abnormalities of the parathyroid glands themselves, such as adenomas or hyperplasia. The patient’s history and laboratory studies can help differentiate between these two conditions. Primary hyperparathyroidism is characterized by an elevated PTH level accompanied by high serum calcium and often normal or low phosphate levels. Secondary hyperparathyroidism typically presents with an elevated PTH level, low or normal serum calcium, and high phosphate levels.

The most common cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism is chronic kidney disease, where impaired renal function leads to phosphate retention, reduced synthesis of active vitamin D, and subsequent decrease in calcium absorption from the GI tract. Malabsorption syndromes, like celiac disease or gastric bypass surgery, can also impair the absorption of calcium and vitamin D. Additionally, severe dietary deficiencies, or the use of certain medications (e.g., bisphosphonates, anticonvulsants, loop diuretics) that affect calcium and vitamin D homeostasis, can also lead to secondary hyperparathyroidism.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Chronic kidney disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diabetes mellitus:
Incorrect: While diabetes can lead to kidney disease, which in turn may cause secondary hyperparathyroidism, it is not a direct causative factor for the condition.  
❌ High calcium diet:
Incorrect: In patients without underlying disorders, a diet high in calcium would typically reduce the risk of hyperparathyroidism by providing adequate calcium, which can suppress parathyroid hormone secretion. In this patient, a calcium-rich diet is not causing hyperparathyroidism, chronic kidney disease is the underlying cause.  
❌ Family history of osteoporosis:
Incorrect: While a family history of osteoporosis may indicate a predisposition to bone density issues, it does not directly relate to this patient’s secondary hyperparathyroidism from chronic kidney disease.  
❌ Active lifestyle:
Incorrect: An active lifestyle would not cause secondary hyperparathyroidism.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman comes to her outpatient provider to evaluate excessive sweating, anxiety, and weight loss despite an increased appetite. Her past medical history is notable for a toxic thyroid adenoma, for which she has been prescribed multiple medications. However, the patient reports that her symptoms have been poorly controlled. In the office, her temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 87/min, and blood pressure is 127/76 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for mild eyelid retraction, and a non-tender, solitary nodule is palpated in the left thyroid lobe. Cardiovascular, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. The physician recommends that the patient undergo treatment that will improve her condition but may cause side effects of hypothyroidism, xerostomia, and sialadenitis. Which of the following best describes this treatment option’s mechanism of action?

choices.text: Removal of autoantibodies from the bloodstream

questions.solution:
This patient has a toxic adenoma, causing symptoms of hyperthyroidism that are refractory to medical management. The patient is started on a radioactive iodine treatment regimen called radioiodine ablation therapy. The isotope of iodine that is used is I131. It is taken orally and eventually gets taken up by the thyroid. Over a few weeks, the radioactive isotope collects in the colloid and emits beta radiation that causes permanent damage to the thyroid.

Radioiodine ablation therapy can provide definitive treatment for hyperthyroidism caused by Graves disease, toxic multinodular goiter, and toxic adenoma. Since the thyroid is permanently destroyed, the patient will need to take thyroid hormone replacements like levothyroxine to prevent hypothyroidism. Radioactive iodine crosses the placenta and is secreted in breast milk. Hence, it is contraindicated in pregnant or breastfeeding individuals. Finally, as far as side effects go, radioactive iodide can cause radiation-induced thyroiditis, increased risk of neoplasia, hematopoietic suppression, exacerbation of Graves ophthalmopathy, salivary, and lacrimal toxicity. Salivary and lacrimal toxicity arise since the radioactive iodine can also be uptaken by these glands and cause tissue damage.  

Option Analysis

❌ Non-selective blockade of beta-receptors:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of non-selective beta-blockers (e.g. propranolol). Side effects may include bradycardia, fatigue, bronchoconstriction/asthma exacerbation, and weight gain. However, this medication class would not cause the side effects described in the question stem.  
✅ Radiation-induced thyroid gland destruction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Inhibition of thyroid peroxidase:
Incorrect: Thionamides (e.g., methimazole, propylthiouracil) block thyroid hormone production by inhibiting thyroid peroxidase. Side effects include agranulocytosis, hepatotoxicity, aplastic anemia, and skin rash. However, thionamides would not cause the side effects described in the question stem.  
❌ Promotion of lymphocyte apoptosis:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids are immunosuppressants that function via several mechanisms of action. One involves promoting the apoptosis of lymphocytes, monocytes, and other immune cells. The medication treats Graves ophthalmopathy and thyroid storm, but not toxic adenoma. Side effects include hyperglycemia, skin atrophy, weight gain, and increased infection risk.  
❌ Removal of autoantibodies from the bloodstream:
Incorrect: This answer choice describes the mechanism of action of plasmapheresis. It is occasionally used in the management of severe Graves disease. However, plasmapheresis would not be useful in treating a toxic adenoma, given that autoantibodies do not mediate the condition.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old woman presents to the emergency department due to palpitations and feeling that her heart is racing. She reports a 2-months history of restlessness, excessive sweating, and unintentional weight loss of 3 kg. Past medical history is unremarkable. Family history is significant for celiac disease in her mother. Temperature is 37.2°C (99°F), blood pressure is 140/78, pulse is 136/min, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears restless. A fine tremor is seen when her hands and fingers are outstretched. The ECG is shown below. The remainder of the physical examination is most likely to show which of the following?
 

Picture taken from openi
questions.solution:
This patient presents with palpitations, unintentional weight loss, restlessness, excessive sweating, and a fine tremor on examination. Together, these signs and symptoms suggest a diagnosis of hyperthyroidism. Given this patient’s young age and family history of autoimmune disease, Graves disease is the most likely etiology. Ophthalmic signs of Graves disease include proptosis (exophthalmos) and periorbital edema.

Graves disease is an autoimmune disorder caused by autoantibodies that bind to and stimulate the thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) receptor on the thyroid gland, leading to an increase in the size and activity of the gland. This results in a hypermetabolic state, causing signs and symptoms of hyperthyroidism such as palpitations, heat intolerance, anxiety, insomnia, and gastrointestinal issues.

Additionally, Graves disease may result in Graves ophthalmopathy which is characterized by eyelid retraction, periorbital edema, and protrusion of the eyeballs due to retro-orbital inflammation (proptosis). The inflammation is driven by the same autoantibodies that stimulate the thyroid gland, leading to swelling and congestion of the tissues behind the eyes. Graves disease can also result in pretibial myxedema, or thyroid dermatopathy, which is non-pitting edema and skin thickening over the shins due to glycosaminoglycan deposition in the dermis.  

Option Analysis

✅ Proptosis and periorbital edema:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Delayed deep tendon reflexes:
Incorrect: This finding is associated with hypothyroidism, which presents with symptoms such as lethargy, cold intolerance, and weight gain. This patient’s clinical presentation is suggestive of hyperthyroidism where brisk reflexes are typically present.  
❌ Lower limb pitting edema:
Incorrect: While hyperthyroidism can cause non-pitting edema of the lower limbs due to myxedema, pitting edema is not typically seen. It is often seen in conditions like congestive heart failure, nephrotic syndrome, or liver disease.  
❌ Cold dry skin:
Incorrect: Cold dry skin can be seen with hypothyroidism. Warm moist skin is associated with hyperthyroidism.  
❌ Conjunctival pallor and spoon nails:
Incorrect: These findings can indicate iron deficiency anemia, which could cause fatigue and possibly tachycardia. However, the presence of weight loss, restlessness, and fine tremor are more suggestive of hyperthyroidism.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman comes to her primary care provider for an evaluation of fatigue. The patient feels tired each morning even after receiving more than 8 hours of sleep and has difficulty concentrating at her job as a computer programmer. She has also gained 5-kg (11-lb) over the past three months. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 109/72 mmHg, and pulse is 63/min. Physical examination is notable for periorbital swelling and dry skin. The patient has delayed deep tendon reflexes in the lower extremities. Laboratory testing reveals fasting glucose of 93 mg/dL, elevated LDL, and elevated triglycerides. Which of the following medications is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents fatigue, weight gain, delayed deep tendon reflexes, periorbital swelling, and lipid panel abnormalities. These findings are suggestive of hypothyroidism, which is typically treated with levothyroxine.

Levothyroxine is a synthetic form of T4 and can treat primary, secondary, and tertiary hypothyroidism. The medication is converted into its active metabolite L-triiodothyronine (T3) at target cells by the enzyme 5’-deiodinase. Levothyroxine is a slow-acting drug, and it may take 6-8 weeks of therapy before patients achieve normal T4 and T3 levels.

Another medication used to treat hypothyroidism is liothyronine, a synthetic form of T3. Since it is a T3 analog, liothyronine is fast-acting and can be used in emergencies such as myxedema coma.

Synthetic hormones can cause hyperthyroidism, osteoporosis (due to increased bone resorption and remodeling), and hyperglycemia as side effects. The side effect profile is generally more severe for liothyronine, which is more potent than levothyroxine.

Both levothyroxine and liothyronine are contraindicated in patients with uncontrolled adrenal insufficiency, as these medications increase hepatic glucocorticoid metabolism and predispose patients to adrenal crisis. Furthermore, liothyronine is contraindicated in patients with heart disease since it increases the risk of cardiac arrhythmias.  

Option Analysis

✅ Levothyroxine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Metyrapone:
Incorrect: Metyrapone is an inhibitor of 11ꞵ-hydroxylase and blocks cortisol synthesis. The medication is occasionally used to treat Cushing syndrome. Although Cushing syndrome may account for this patient’s fatigue and weight gain, it would not account for the delayed reflexes or dry skin. Furthermore, Cushing syndrome is associated with hypertension and hyperglycemia, which are absent in this patient.  
❌ Fluoxetine:
Incorrect: Fluoxetine is a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor and is the first-line drug in treating depression. However, depression would not account for the delayed reflexes, periorbital swelling, or lipid abnormalities.  
❌ Liothyronine:
Incorrect: Liothyronine is synthetic T3 and can treat hypothyroidism. The medication can quickly take effect after administration and is used in emergencies like myxedema coma. However, its potency also leads to numerous side effects, including anxiety, diarrhea, and cardiac arrhythmias. As a result, levothyroxine (synthetic T4) is preferred over liothyronine in non-emergency situations.  
❌ Bupropion:
Incorrect: Bupropion is an antidepressant that inhibits norepinephrine and dopamine reuptake. The medication has a favorable side-effect profile and promotes weight loss. Although this patient presents with fatigue and weight gain, her additional symptoms of delayed reflexes and periorbital swelling suggest hypothyroidism as the underlying cause.

questions.text:
A 41-year-old woman comes to the physician’s office to evaluate palpitations. The patient has been experiencing intermittent episodes characterized by “a fluttering feeling in my chest.” She has also had a 3 kg (6.6-lb) weight loss and difficulty falling asleep at night. She consumes one cup of coffee each morning but no caffeinated beverages in the afternoon or evening.  Her medical history is notable for Hashimoto thyroiditis, for which she has been taking daily levothyroxine. Temperature is 37.6°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 134/83 mmHg, and pulse is 84/min. Physical examination is notable for warm, moist skin and bilateral hand tremors. Laboratory testing from the current visit, as well as a prior visit six months ago, are shown below. Review of the medical record reveals the patient was started on a new drug a month ago. Which of the following medications was the patient likely started on?  

Laboratory Value  
Current Visit  
Prior Visit  
TSH
0.3 µU/mL  
2.5 µU/mL  
Total T4   
7.0 ng/dL  
6.8 ng/dL  
Free T4   
4.6 ng/dL  
2.1 ng/dL
questions.solution:
This patient, with a history of Hashimoto thyroiditis treated with levothyroxine, presents with symptoms of hyperthyroidism. Laboratory testing reveals a largely unchanged total T4 but markedly increased free (biologically active) T4. Amongst the answer choices, dexamethasone is the medication most likely responsible for these changes.

Patients starting new medications may require adjustments in their levothyroxine dose due to drug-drug interactions.  The first group includes medications that decrease levothyroxine absorption, such as iron, aluminum hydroxide, proton pump inhibitors (PPIs), sucralfate, and cholestyramine. Since they are associated with decreased absorption, individuals taking these medications require higher doses of levothyroxine to achieve therapeutic effects. The next group covers medications that increase thyroid hormone metabolisms, such as rifampin, phenytoin, and carbamazepine. These patients also require higher doses of levothyroxine.

Next, some medications increase the concentration of thyroxine-binding globulins (TBGs), such as estrogen, raloxifene, tamoxifen, heroin, and methadone. More TBGs mean less free T4; therefore, these individuals require more levothyroxine. In contrast, medications such as androgens, glucocorticoids, and anabolic steroids decrease TBG concentration. In other words, fewer TBGs in the blood means more free T4, so these individuals require lower doses of levothyroxine.

Finally, it is important to note that propranolol inhibits 5’- deiodinase and reduces the conversion of T4 to T3. Since propranolol favors the less active form of thyroid hormones, T4, individuals on propranolol also require higher doses of levothyroxine.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Propranolol:
Incorrect: Propranolol inhibits 5’-deiodinase and reduces the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. As a result, propranolol would more likely cause symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., fatigue, dry skin, delayed deep tendon reflexes) rather than hyperthyroidism.  
❌ Methadone:
Incorrect: Methadone increases the plasma concentration of thyroxine-binding globulins (TBG). This effect would reduce the amount of free T4 available. In contrast, this patient has higher levels of T4 after starting the new medication.  
✅ Dexamethasone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Omeprazole:
Incorrect: Proton pump inhibitors such as omeprazole and lansoprazole are known to reduce levothyroxine absorption from the gastrointestinal tract. Reduced levothyroxine bioavailability would result in increased TSH levels, decreased total and free T4 levels, and symptoms of hypothyroidism. In contrast, this patient has decreased TSH levels and increased total and free T4 levels.  
❌ Carbamazepine:
Incorrect: Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant that increases thyroid hormone metabolism. If the patient had been started on carbamazepine, her laboratory results from the current visit would likely demonstrate a reduced total and free T4 levels, which would subsequently lead to an increase in TSH levels.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a six-month history of fatigue, weight gain, and constipation. She also reports bouts of sadness over the same time period. She has no significant past medical history. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her mother has rheumatoid arthritis. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 50/min, and blood pressure is 110/90 mmHg. Palpation of the neck reveals a palpable, smooth, rubbery, non-tender neck mass. That patient’s skin is dry, cold, and rough to the touch. Which of the following evaluations should be performed next to help make the diagnosis?

choices.text: Assessment of TSH and free T4
Performance of rapid ACTH stimulation test

questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with fatigue, weight gain constipation, and feelings of sadness. She has rough and dry skin and an enlarged anterior rubbery neck mass which, taken together, are concerning for hypothyroidism. Laboratory testing with TSH and free T4 should be performed, and if the TSH is elevated and free T4 is low then primary hypothyroidism can be diagnosed.

Hashimoto thyroiditis is the most common cause of primary hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient parts of the world and is the likely cause of primary hypothyroidism in this patient. It results from production of antithyroid peroxidase (anti-TPO) and antithyroglobulin (anti-Tg) antibodies that lead to destruction of thyroid cells and are treated with thyroid hormone replacement.  

Option Analysis

✅ Assessment of TSH and free T4:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Ultrasound of the neck:
Incorrect: For patients with suspected Hashimoto thyroiditis, ultrasound should be reserved for patients with larger goiters, thyroid asymmetry, or thyroid nodularity.  
❌ Assessment for TSH receptor antibodies:
Incorrect: Antibodies to TSH receptors are suggestive of Graves disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. Patients with Graves disease usually present with tachycardia, palpitations, weight loss, hyperhidrosis, warm, moist skin, diarrhea, eye pain, and heat intolerance.  
❌ Evaluation for malnutrition:
Incorrect: Vitamin and mineral deficiencies can manifest as abnormal gastrointestinal and dermatologic findings, such as pellagra due to niacin deficiency or neuropathy due to vitamin B12 deficiency. The constellation of this patient’s findings are not suggestive of a vitamin or mineral deficiency.  
❌ Performance of rapid ACTH stimulation test:
Incorrect: The rapid ACTH stimulation test is used in the diagnosis of adrenocortical insufficiency (ie, Addison disease). Signs and symptoms of Addison’s disease include hyperpigmentation, weakness, fatigue, weight loss, salt craving, and dizziness with orthostasis.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with altered mental status. The patient has a past medical history of hypertension, osteopenia and recurrent kidney stones. Temperature is 37.0 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 54/min, respiratory rate is 12/min, blood pressure is 150/90 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the patient is somnolent but awakens to touch, and the abdomen is diffusely tender to palpation. Skin and mucous membranes are dry. ECG demonstrates sinus bradycardia and a shortened QT interval. Laboratory testing shows a serum calcium level of 14.5 mg/dL. In addition to aggressive IV fluid hydration, what is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of osteopenia and recurrent kidney stones in conjunction with this acute episode of severe, symptomatic hypercalcemia is consistent with a hyperparathyroid crisis. The initial goal is to reduce serum calcium levels with aggressive IV hydration. Bisphosphonates, such as zoledronic acid, should also be given.

Primary hyperparathyroidism is one of the most common causes of hypercalcemia. In this condition, the parathyroid glands secrete excess parathyroid hormone (PTH). As a result, there is increased bone resorption, decreased renal excretion of calcium, and increased intestinal absorption of calcium. This can result in diminished bone mineral density and signs and symptoms of elevated serum calcium levels (e.g., recurrent nephrolithiasis).

The condition is often mild and asymptomatic. However, severe hypercalcemia can occur. Patients can present with altered mental status, weakness, polyuria and polydipsia, nausea, abdominal pain, constipation, hypertension, and bradycardia. ECG findings of bradycardia, atrioventricular block, and shortened QT interval may be seen. Measuring the serum calcium level will confirm that hypercalcemia is present.

In severe hypercalcemia, initial treatment is aggressive IV fluid hydration to correct the underlying volume depletion. In addition, antiresorptive therapy with bisphosphonates, namely zoledronic acid or pamidronate, can be initiated. Once the patient’s volume status has normalized (or if hypervolemia occurs), loop diuretics may also be used judiciously. Ultimately, parathyroidectomy is the definitive treatment for primary hyperparathyroidism, but the diagnosis must be confirmed with appropriate testing.  

Option Analysis

✅ IV zoledronic acid:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Parathyroidectomy:
Incorrect: Parathyroidectomy is indicated for definitive treatment in patients with symptomatic primary hyperparathyroidism, but it is not the immediate step for managing acute hypercalcemia due to hyperparathyroidism. Additionally, confirmation of hyperparathyroidism is required before surgery.  
❌ IV furosemide:
Incorrect: Loop diuretics are used in the management of acute hypercalcemia from hyperparathyroidism. However, these are typically initiated as adjunct therapy only after the patient’s volume depletion is corrected.  
❌ Oral calcium carbonate:
Incorrect: This patient has severe hypercalcemia related to hyperparathyroidism. Calcium supplementation could worsen hypercalcemia.  
❌ Oral alendronate:
Incorrect: Bisphosphonates are used in the management of severe hypercalcemia due to hyperparathyroidism. However, IV zoledronic acid or pamidronate are the most appropriate options.

questions.text: A 47-year-old woman with a history of kidney stones presents for evaluation of fatigue, depression and bone pain for several months. The patient’s sister was recently diagnosed with thyroid cancer and their father has a history of pheochromocytoma. Physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies show elevated serum calcium and parathyroid hormone levels. Neck ultrasound demonstrates an enlarged left parathyroid gland. Which additional test should be performed next to further evaluate this patient's underlying condition?

choices.text: Genetic testing for a RET mutation
Genetic testing for a MEN1 mutation

questions.solution:
This patient’s symptoms and laboratory studies are suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism likely from a parathyroid adenoma. Additionally, this patient’s family history of thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma is suggestive of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN), type 2. Thus, genetic testing for a RET mutation is warranted.

In primary hyperparathyroidism, the parathyroid glands secrete excess parathyroid hormone (PTH). As a result, there is increased bone resorption, decreased renal excretion of calcium, and increased intestinal absorption of calcium, resulting in hypercalcemia. Causes of primary hyperparathyroidism include parathyroid adenomas, which is likely in this patient, multiglandular hyperplasia (formerly parathyroid hyperplasia), and parathyroid carcinoma.

Taking a full history is critical, particularly since parathyroid adenomas are one type of tumor associated with both MEN1 and MEN2A. If the patient has personal or family history suggesting these disorders, genetic testing should be pursued. This can be accomplished with an evaluation for mutations in the MEN1 (for MEN1) or RET (for MEN2A) genes. If positive, screening for additional tumors is warranted.
 

Option Analysis

✅ Genetic testing for a RET mutation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Serum gastrin level:
Incorrect: This test is used to evaluate for gastrinoma, a component of multiple endocrine neoplasia type 1 (MEN1). However, this patient’s family history of thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma is more concerning for MEN2A.  
❌ Serum phosphate level:
Incorrect: While hypophosphatemia is a common finding in primary hyperparathyroidism, it is a nonspecific test and would not provide additional diagnostic information in this patient’s case. It can sometimes be used to differentiate between primary and tertiary hyperparathyroidism.  
❌ MRI of the brain:
Incorrect: Pituitary adenoma is a component of MEN1, which would be evident on a brain MRI. However, this patient’s clinical picture is more concerning for MEN2A given the family history of thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma.  
❌ Genetic testing for a MEN1 mutation:
Incorrect: MEN1 mutation testing is used to diagnose MEN1, which commonly presents with tumors of the pituitary, parathyroid, and pancreas. However, this patient’s history is more suggestive of MEN2A given the family history of thyroid cancer and pheochromocytoma.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, G1P0, at eight weeks gestation, comes to the clinic because of heat intolerance, excessive sweating, and thinning hair. The symptoms began six months ago. Medical history is notable for seasonal allergies. Family history is notable for type I diabetes mellitus and rheumatoid arthritis. She does not use alcohol, tobacco, or recreational drugs. In the office, her temperature is 37.6°C (99.7°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 126/80 mmHg. Physical examination is notable for a symmetrically-enlarged, nontender thyroid gland. A fine tremor is observed bilaterally in the patient’s hands when outstretched. Cardiovascular, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. Which drugs are most appropriate for treating this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has hyperthyroidism in the setting of a symmetrical, non-tender thyroid, which raises concerns for Graves disease. Thionamides (e.g., methimazole, propylthiouracil) are commonly used treatment options. Thionamides work by preventing thyroid hormone synthesis via inhibition of thyroid peroxidase. In addition, propylthiouracil (PTU) prevents the peripheral conversion of T4 to T3 via inhibition of 5’-deiodinase.

It is important to note that methimazole and propylthiouracil (PTU) are used in pregnancy even though they can cross the placenta. However, during the first trimester, when organogenesis is taking place, the fetus is susceptible to drug-induced damage, and thus PTU is preferred. The rationale is that PTU is less likely to cross the placenta due to its extensive plasma protein binding. On the other hand, methimazole is contraindicated during the first trimester because it is associated with aplasia cutis, a condition characterized by the absence of a portion of skin. Then, during the second and third trimesters, once organogenesis is complete, methimazole is preferred due to its lower risk of hepatotoxicity.

Patients taking thionamides require close monitoring of thyroid and liver function and should be educated on symptoms and signs that should prompt medical review.  

Option Analysis

❌ Methimazole:
Incorrect: Methimazole is an oral anti-thyroid drug commonly used to treat hyperthyroidism in the general population. However, methimazole is contraindicated during the first trimester because it is teratogenic and is associated with fetal aplasia cutis, a condition characterized by the absence of a portion of skin.  
❌ Oxytocin:
Incorrect: Oxytocin is released by the posterior pituitary gland and helps to stimulate uterine contractions during labor. It can be given exogenously to assist with labor complications but would not treat hyperthyroidism.  
✅ Propylthiouracil:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Radioactive iodine:
Incorrect: Radioactive iodine is a treatment option for hyperthyroidism. However, radioactive iodine crosses the placenta and is secreted in breast milk. Hence, it is contraindicated in pregnant or breastfeeding individuals.  
❌ Synthetic T4  :
Incorrect: Synthetic T4, commonly known as levothyroxine, is used to treat hypothyroidism. However, this patient has heat intolerance, excessive sweating, and hair thinning, which are symptoms of hyperthyroidism. Administering levothyroxine to this patient would exacerbate her condition.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 2-day history of severe palpitations, dyspnea, restlessness, and fever. She also reports intermittent episodes of diarrhea over the past 2 days. She has a history of Graves' disease but has been taking her prescribed methimazole inconsistently. Temperature is 39.6°C (103.2°F), pulse is 150/min and irregular, blood pressure is 145/95 mm Hg, respiratory rate is 26/min, and oxygen saturation is 92% on room air. She appears agitated and diaphoretic on examination. Her skin is warm and moist to the touch, and she has an enlarged, non-tender thyroid gland. Neurological examination shows the presence of fine tremors and hyperreflexia. Laboratory studies reveal decreased thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH), increased free thyroxine (T4), and increased triiodothyronine (T3). An ECG shows atrial fibrillation. Intravenous fluids are initiated. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with severe palpitations, restlessness, and fever, accompanied by signs of hyperthyroidism and laboratory findings of decreased TSH and increased T4 and T3 levels. These findings, along with her history of Graves' disease and medication noncompliance, are consistent with the diagnosis of thyroid storm, which is a severe, life-threatening form of thyrotoxicosis. Given this patient’s dyspnea and tachypnea secondary to atrial fibrillation, the best next step in management is to stabilize this patient by giving propranolol (non-selective beta-blocker).

Presenting symptoms of thyroid storm often include a severe increase in metabolic activity, leading to agitation, fever, tachycardia, and gastrointestinal symptoms such as diarrhea. In addition, elevated thyroid hormone levels may result in a hyperadrenergic state, characterized by palpitations, tremors, and hyperreflexia.

The acute management of thyroid storm aims to control the adrenergic symptoms (beta blocker), inhibit new thyroid hormone synthesis (thionamide), block the release of preformed thyroid hormone (iodine), and prevent the peripheral conversion of thyroxine (T4) to the more potent triiodothyronine (T3) (glucocorticoids). These can be achieved by a combination of propranolol or other beta-blockers, propylthiouracil, and prednisolone or other glucocorticoids, followed by potassium iodide one hour after the administration of a thionamide. Surgery is reserved for patients with contraindications to thioamides who require urgent correction of hyperthyroidism.  

Option Analysis

✅ Administration of propranolol:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administration of iodine solution:
Incorrect: Iodine is used to block the release of preformed thyroid hormone and is typically administered one hour after administration of a thionamide. Controlling the adrenergic signs and symptoms including arrhythmia with propranolol is the first step in management.  
❌ Emergent thyroidectomy:
Incorrect: Surgery is not the first-line treatment for thyroid storm and is typically reserved for patients with contraindications to thioamides who require urgent correction of hyperthyroidism.  
❌ Administration of amiodarone:
Incorrect: While amiodarone can manage arrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation, it can potentially exacerbate thyroid dysfunction due to its high iodine content.  
❌ Administration of broad-spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: Antibiotics are not indicated unless there's a suspicion of a precipitating infection. This patient's symptoms are more likely due to thyroid storm from medication non-compliance than to infection.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents to the primary care office for evaluation of fatigue, weight gain, and constipation. She has also been noticing hair loss over the last month and has had daily headaches. She states that when she is driving, it seems harder than usual to see other cars coming up on either side of her. Past medical history is otherwise unremarkable. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 62/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 118/78 mmHg.  On exam, she appears tired with slight pallor and dry skin. Testing of the visual fields by confrontation reveals a loss of peripheral vision bilaterally. Abdomen is soft and nontender with no masses palpated. Initial laboratory evaluation reveals a TSH of 0.35 mIU/L and a serum-free T<sub>4</sub> of 0.68 ng/dL. Hemoglobin is 12.6 g/dL. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is experiencing visual changes, headaches, and symptoms of hypothyroidism likely due to a pituitary adenoma.  Pituitary adenomas can affect hormone production from the gland as well as cause local effects from the mass.  Compression at the optic chiasm leads to loss of peripheral vision in both eyes and is known as bitemporal hemianopsia.  A contrast-enhanced MRI of the brain will confirm the diagnosis.  Pituitary adenomas are a form of secondary hypothyroidism, affecting the pituitary-thyroid axis where there is insufficient stimulation of the thyroid gland by the pituitary hormones.  Patients will therefore present with both low TSH and low serum free T4.

In addition to tumors, other etiologies that can interfere with the hypothalamic-pituitary axis and lead to central hypothyroidism include infections such as meningitis or encephalitis, inflammation including autoimmune destruction of the glands, iatrogenic caused by brain surgery or radiation and infiltrative processes such as sarcoidosis and amyloidosis.  Historical context can help narrow this differential.  In these central processes, other pituitary hormones are also likely to be affected including ACTH, FSH, LH, GH, and prolactin.  Assessment of these and their concomitant conditions should be included in the workup.  

Option Analysis

✅ Pituitary adenoma:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Sarcoidosis:
Incorrect:  Sarcoidosis can cause central hypothyroidism, but the history of headaches and peripheral vision loss makes a pituitary adenoma causing compression of the optic chiasm more likely.  
❌ Hashimoto thyroiditis:
Incorrect: Hashimoto thyroiditis is a cause of primary hypothyroidism. TSH would be expected to be elevated and serum-free T4 would be low.  
❌ Iodine deficiency:
Incorrect: Iodine deficiency is a cause of primary hypothyroidism.  Therefore TSH would be elevated and serum-free T4 low.  
❌ Amyloidosis:
Incorrect: Amyloidosis can lead to secondary hypothyroidism through amyloid infiltration of the pituitary tissue or primary hypothyroidism through direct infiltration of the thyroid gland; however, the history of headaches and peripheral visual loss in the absence of other signs of amyloidosis makes a pituitary adenoma causing compression of the optic chiasm the more likely cause of hypothyroidism.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a six-month history of weight gain and fatigue. She says she always feels cold and has to continuously cover-up. She initially attributed these symptoms to a recent divorce. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 53/min, and blood pressure is 110/95 mmHg. Palpation of the neck reveals a smooth, non-tender anterior mass. The patient’s skin is dry, cold, and rough to the touch. Laboratory studies show TSH of 12.3 mIU/L, a free T4 of 0.71 mIU/L, and the presence of anti-Tg antibodies. Which of the following additional findings is most consistent with this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presenting with fatigue, weight gain, dry skin, cold intolerance, elevated TSH and low free T4 has primary hypothyroidism. The presence of antithyroid (anti-TPO) or antithyroglobulin (anti-Tg) antibodies confirms the diagnosis of Hashimoto Thyroiditis. On physical examination patients with hypothyroidism can have bradycardia, delayed relaxation of the deep tendon reflexes, peripheral edema, palpable (non-tender) smooth goiter, and diastolic hypertension.

Central hypothyroidism is another cause of hypothyroidism. It is a non-autoimmune cause of hypothyroidism and results in insufficient stimulation of the thyroid gland by TSH. It is either caused by hypothalamic (tertiary) or pituitary (secondary) disease. This should be suspected in cases where there is known hypothalamic or pituitary disease, a pituitary mass, or when hypothyroidism symptoms are associated with abnormal hormonal levels typically with both a low TSH and free T4.  

Option Analysis

✅ Diastolic hypertension:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Diarrhea:
Incorrect: Hyperthyroidism typically presents with tachycardia, palpitations, weight loss, hyperhidrosis, warm, moist skin, diarrhea, and heat intolerance. Hypothyroidism is typically associated with constipation.  
❌ Hypothermia:
Incorrect: Myxedema coma is a severe, life-threatening form of hypothyroidism that presents with hypothermia, bradycardia, hypoventilation, and lethargy. This patient is stable and therefore would not likely have hypothermia.  
❌ TSH receptor antibodies:
Incorrect: Antibodies to TSH receptors are suggestive of Graves disease, the most common cause of hyperthyroidism. Patients with Graves disease typically present with tachycardia, palpitations, weight loss, hyperhidrosis, warm, moist skin, diarrhea, eye pain, and heat intolerance.  
❌ Diaphoresis:
Incorrect: Tachycardia, heat intolerance, diaphoresis, increased appetite, and weight loss can be seen in Hashitoxicosis which rarely may be an early stage of Hashimoto thyroiditis. This patient is in the hypothyroidism phase.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the clinic with fatigue and constipation. She works as a corporate lawyer and has been working 80-hour weeks for the past three months. She also reports weight gain of 6.8 kg (15 lb) and episodes of sadness during the past six months. She has no significant past medical history and takes no medications. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 65/min, and blood pressure is 115/95 mmHg. The patient’s skin is dry, cold, and rough to the touch. Laboratory studies show a TSH level of 12.3 mIU/L, free T4 of 0.70 mIU/L, and the presence of anti-TPO antibodies. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
Fatigue, constipation, weight gain, depression, and results of laboratory studies are suggestive of primary hypothyroidism in this patient. Primary hypothyroidism is most commonly caused by Hashimoto thyroiditis in iodine-sufficient parts of the world. In some cases, patients have a period of hyperthyroidism followed by chronic hypothyroidism. In a stable patient presenting with Hashimoto thyroiditis who has a TSH level greater than 10 mIU/L, treatment consists of thyroid replacement therapy with levothyroxine.

Once treatment with levothyroxine has been started, patients should be reevaluated 3-6 weeks later to assess treatment response. If TSH levels are normal, current dosing should be continued. If TSH levels are still elevated, the dose should be uptitrated until TSH levels have normalized. Patients typically require lifelong therapy and should be routinely followed up at least once a year. The primary goal of treatment is to achieve a euthyroid state.  

Option Analysis

✅ Levothyroxine:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Stress dose glucocorticoids:
Incorrect: Myxedema coma presents with hypothermia, bradycardia, hypoventilation, and lethargy and is a severe, life-threatening form of hypothyroidism. Treatment consists of supportive care (eg, ventilatory support), corticosteroids, and thyroid replacement therapy). Given the lack of these findings and evidence of a moderately elevated (and not severely elevated) TSH, this patient does not have myxedema coma.  
❌ Metoprolol:
Incorrect: Hashitoxicosis can be treated with beta-blockers. It is a rare phase of hyperthyroidism that can be seen in Hashimoto thyroiditis. This patient has clinical findings and lab studies consistent with hypothyroidism.  
❌ Radioiodine therapy:
Incorrect: Graves disease can be treated with radioiodine therapy. It is the most common cause of hyperthyroidism and presents with tachycardia, palpitations, weight loss, diarrhea, and heat intolerance.  
❌ Vitamin B12:
Incorrect: Vitamin B12 deficiency can present with fatigue (macrocytic anemia) and glossitis (macroglossia). However, given the constellation of findings in this patient, vitamin B12 deficiency is not a likely diagnosis, and vitamin B12 supplementation would not be an appropriate treatment.

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man with a history of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass surgery five years ago presents to the clinic for follow up of abnormal laboratory findings. The patient has no specific symptoms and has maintained his significant weight loss since the surgery. He generally follows a balanced diet but does have intermittent issues with diarrhea. Vital signs are within normal limits and physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory studies are shown below. What is the most appropriate next step in management?  

Laboratory study
Result
Calcium
8.2 mg/dL  
25-hydroxy vitamin D  
10 ng/mL  
Parathyroid hormone  
88 pg/mL
questions.solution:
This patient’s history of gastric bypass surgery and current laboratory values suggest a diagnosis of secondary hyperparathyroidism related to malabsorption and chronic hypocalcemia. Supplementation with calcium and vitamin D is indicated.

Hyperparathyroidism is a condition characterized by excessive production of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands. The condition is categorized into three types: primary, secondary and tertiary. Primary hyperparathyroidism is typically caused by parathyroid adenoma or hyperplasia, leading to unregulated overproduction of PTH and often resulting in elevated serum calcium. Secondary hyperparathyroidism is a response to chronic hypocalcemia, commonly due to chronic kidney disease or dietary deficiencies, where the parathyroid glands are compensating for the low calcium by producing more PTH. Tertiary hyperparathyroidism is a progression of secondary hyperparathyroidism where the parathyroid glands become hyperactive and autonomous, continuing to produce high levels of PTH even after the initial cause of secondary hyperparathyroidism has been treated or resolved.

The management of hyperparathyroidism is based on the type of hyperparathyroidism. In primary hyperparathyroidism, surgery is often the preferred treatment, especially in symptomatic cases. In asymptomatic cases, careful monitoring may be sufficient. For secondary hyperparathyroidism, particularly when it is related to malabsorption disorders such as celiac disease or post-gastric bypass surgery, the emphasis is on correcting nutrient deficiencies including supplementing with calcium and vitamin D, and managing any underlying malabsorptive conditions. Tertiary hyperparathyroidism, which develops from prolonged secondary hyperparathyroidism, typically requires surgical intervention due to the parathyroid glands' autonomous functioning.  

Option Analysis

✅ Vitamin D and calcium supplementation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Furosemide:
Incorrect: A loop diuretic is not indicated in this scenario as it can promote calcium loss through urine. This patient already has a low calcium level and vitamin D and calcium supplementation is necessary.  
❌ Zoledronic acid:
Incorrect: This is a bisphosphonate typically used in the treatment of hypercalcemia. In this patient who has a mildly low calcium level and no evidence of primary hyperparathyroidism or malignancy, zoledronic acid is not appropriate.  
❌ Cinacalcet:
Incorrect: Calcimimetics are used to lower parathyroid hormone levels in conditions like primary hyperparathyroidism or secondary hyperparathyroidism due to chronic kidney disease. There is no indication of this medication in this patient.  
❌ Parathyroidectomy:
Incorrect: This is an option for the management of primary or tertiary hyperparathyroidism. However, this patient has secondary hyperparathyroidism related to malabsorption of calcium and vitamin D, therefore vitamin D and calcium supplementation are necessary.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, comes to the clinic at five weeks gestation for her initial prenatal visit. The patient is feeling well and has no acute complaints. Past medical history is notable for hypothyroidism secondary to Hashimoto thyroiditis, well-managed with levothyroxine. Temperature is 37.5°C (99.5°F), blood pressure is 115/73 mmHg, and pulse is 72/min. Physical examination yields no concerning findings. The most recent TSH is 2.5 µU/mL. Which of the following is the most appropriate approach to managing the patient’s hypothyroidism as her pregnancy progresses?
questions.solution:
This patient has hypothyroidism that is being treated with levothyroxine, which is a synthetic form of T4. Although the patient is asymptomatic and her TSH is within normal limits, thyroid hormone requirements increase throughout pregnancy. To meet these increased demands, patients will need to increase their levothyroxine dose by 30-50%.

These changes occur since during pregnancy. Increased estrogen levels lead to increased synthesis of thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG). Increased TBG means more bound (biologically inactive) T4 and less free (biologically active) T4.

Thyroid function tests should be repeated regularly throughout pregnancy to guide additional dosage adjustments. Close follow-up is required since overt hypothyroidism during pregnancy is associated with adverse outcomes, including an increased rate of first-trimester spontaneous abortion, preeclampsia, congenital anomalies, and congenital hypothyroidism.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Decrease her levothyroxine dose:
Incorrect: Thyroid hormone requirements increase during pregnancy. Pregnancy increases plasma thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) concentrations, decreasing the amount of free (biologically active) T4. As a result, patients will require a higher dose of levothyroxine during pregnancy.  
❌ Discontinue levothyroxine and begin liotrix:
Incorrect: Liotrix consists of levothyroxine (synthetic T4) and liothyronine (synthetic T3). Although liotrix is not associated with adverse maternal or fetal outcomes, the medication also does not provide any additional benefit over levothyroxine.  
❌ Discontinue levothyroxine until after delivery:
Incorrect: Discontinuing levothyroxine would cause uncontrolled maternal hypothyroidism, which would result in adverse fetal and maternal outcomes. Medication should maintain normal maternal thyroid function before conception and throughout pregnancy. Furthermore, patients diagnosed with hypothyroidism before conception will generally require a higher dose of levothyroxine during pregnancy.  
✅ Increase her levothyroxine dose:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Maintain levothyroxine dose:
Incorrect: Thyroid hormone requirements increase during pregnancy. Pregnancy increases plasma thyroxine-binding globulin concentrations, decreasing the amount of free (biologically active) T4. Thus, this patient will require a higher dose of levothyroxine.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman comes to a surgeon after her primary care physician noticed a lump in her neck. A biopsy is performed, and the samples are sent to pathology for analysis, revealing follicular thyroid cancer. The patient is scheduled for a total thyroidectomy. During the operation, a nerve near the superior thyroid artery is injured. Which of the following structures was most likely injured?

choices.text: External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve
Pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve

questions.solution:
The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve travels close to the superior thyroid artery and can be easily injured in thyroid surgeries.  

The superior laryngeal nerve is a branch of the vagus nerve. It subsequently divides into the external and internal branches. The external branch supplies the cricothyroid muscle and helps tense the vocal cords. This branch travels along the lateral surface of the inferior constrictor muscle of the pharynx and closely follows the superior thyroid artery. As a result, it is susceptible to injury during thyroidectomy. The resultant neurological effects include ipsilateral anesthesia of the larynx above the level of the vocal cords and paralysis of the cricothyroid muscle. Most cases of unilateral paralysis are asymptomatic. However, symptomatic patients may experience a weak voice, occasional hoarseness, and voice quality and pitch changes.  



The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve provides sensory innervation to the mucosa of the supraglottic larynx. This branch enters the larynx through the thyrohyoid membrane and courses relatively far from the thyroid. As a result, it is not typically injured in thyroidectomy. However, the superior laryngeal nerve as a whole can be damaged during skull base surgery, resulting in a loss of sensation of the superior laryngeal mucosa.   

Option Analysis

✅ External branch of the superior laryngeal nerve :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve :
Incorrect: The internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve enters the larynx through the thyrohyoid membrane. The nerve does not course near the thyroid and, as a result, is not commonly injured during thyroidectomies. 
❌ The recurrent laryngeal nerve :
Incorrect: The recurrent laryngeal nerve can be injured during thyroidectomies when dissecting the inferior thyroid artery due to their proximity. However, the nerve injured in this patient courses near the superior thyroid artery.
❌ Accessory nerve:
Incorrect: The accessory nerve is not susceptible to injury during thyroidectomies. 
❌ Pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve :
Incorrect: The pharyngeal branches of the vagus nerve are not susceptible to injury during thyroidectomies.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman comes to the physician for an evaluation of hoarseness. The patient underwent total thyroidectomy for treatment of thyroid carcinoma one month ago and subsequently developed hoarseness of the voice. Initially, she thought the symptom was just a transient side effect of the operation. However, when the symptoms persisted, she decided to seek further medical care. Vitals are within normal limits. The strength and sensation of the head and neck are intact. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are unremarkable. Direct laryngoscopy reveals paralysis of the right vocal cord. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Injury to the right recurrent laryngeal nerve during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery
Injury to the right recurrent laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery
Injury to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery.
Injury to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery
Injury to the right internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery

questions.solution:
This patient presents with hoarseness and unilateral vocal cord paralysis following a thyroidectomy. These findings are most likely due to recurrent laryngeal nerve injury during intraoperative dissection of the inferior thyroid artery.  

The recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN) is a branch of the vagus nerve. The RLN innervates all intrinsic muscles of the larynx except the cricothyroid muscle, which is supplied by the external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve. The recurrent laryngeal nerve also provides sensory supply to the larynx below the level of the vocal cords (subglottic sensation) and motor supply to the vocal cords.  

The right RLN descends with the rest of the vagus nerve anterior to the right subclavian artery before branching off and winding back around it posteriorly to course cranially in the tracheoesophageal groove toward the larynx. The right laryngeal nerve courses closely with the inferior thyroid artery at the junction of the lower and middle thirds of the thyroid. The left recurrent laryngeal nerve courses with the vagus nerve before branching and winding posteriorly around the aortic arch, subsequently ascending through the superior mediastinum and the tracheoesophageal groove towards the larynx. Both branches of the recurrent laryngeal nerve then enter the larynx below the inferior constrictor to supply the muscles and mucosa of the larynx.  

 


During a total thyroidectomy, patients are at risk of developing unilateral or bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve paralysis. Unilateral injury can cause paralysis to the true vocal cord and intrinsic muscles of the larynx. Clinically, patients can present with hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. Bilateral injury to the recurrent laryngeal nerve can cause stridor, airway compromise, and respiratory distress. It may necessitate a tracheostomy.  

 

Option Analysis

✅ Injury to the right recurrent laryngeal nerve during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Injury to the right recurrent laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery:
Incorrect: The recurrent laryngeal nerve is susceptible to injury in thyroidectomies due to its proximity to the inferior thyroid artery, not the superior thyroid artery. 
❌ Injury to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery. :
Incorrect: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is susceptible to injury in thyroidectomies due to its proximity to the superior thyroid artery. This nerve is responsible for supplying the cricothyroid muscle of the larynx. Damage to this nerve may cause changes to the pitch of a patient’s voice. However, vocal cord paralysis is more suggestive of recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.
❌ Injury to the right external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the inferior thyroid artery:
Incorrect: The external branch of the superior laryngeal nerve is susceptible to injury in thyroidectomies due to its proximity to the superior thyroid artery, not the inferior thyroid artery. Injury to this nerve may cause changes to the pitch of a patient’s voice. However, vocal cord paralysis is more suggestive of recurrent laryngeal nerve injury.
❌ Injury to the right internal branch of the superior laryngeal nerve during dissection of the superior thyroid artery :
Incorrect: The internal branch provides sensory supply to the mucosa of the supraglottic larynx. It enters the larynx through the thyrohyoid membrane and courses relatively far from the thyroid. As a result, it is not typically injured in thyroidectomy.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is currently postoperative day two in the surgical intensive care unit post total thyroidectomy for anaplastic thyroid carcinoma. During rounds, the patient reports a sensation of numbness around her lips and mouth and intermittent twitching of her upper and lower extremities. The patient's temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 156/67 mmHg, and O2. is 95% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates an intact incision over the anterior neck without edema or erythema.  A routine electrocardiogram is demonstrated below.  Which of the following laboratory findings is most likely to be present based on this patient’s clinical presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient presents after total thyroidectomy with findings of circumoral numbness, tetany, and a prolonged QT interval on routine electrocardiographic screening, consistent with hypocalcemia. In the setting of a recent thyroidectomy, the most likely etiology of hypocalcemia is removal or damage to the parathyroid glands, resulting in hypoparathyroidism. The laboratory findings most reflective of this clinical condition is choice A.  

Multiple structures are at risk of injury during thyroidectomy or hemithyroidectomy, including surrounding glands, vasculature, and nerves (e.g., recurrent laryngeal nerves, external branches of the superior laryngeal nerves). Injury to the parathyroid glands can produce transient or permanent hypoparathyroidism. For this reason, many patients undergoing this procedure are empirically prescribed calcium supplementation to avoid complications associated with hypocalcemia.    

Symptoms of hypoparathyroidism and associated hypocalcemia include muscle tetany, paresthesias, seizures, and psychiatric symptoms (e.g., emotional instability, anxiety, depression). Moreover, hypocalcemia can cause cardiovascular compromise, resulting in QT interval prolongation on ECG, which can degenerate into torsade de pointes. Physical exam findings include the Chvostek sign and Trousseau sign (carpal spasms triggered by inflation of a sphygmomanometer).  

Option Analysis

✅                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↓  ↑  ↓ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↓  ↑  ↑:
Incorrect: Secondary hypoparathyroidism, due to chronic kidney disease, manifests with decreased levels of calcium, increased levels of phosphate, and increased parathyroid hormone. These effects are secondary to the kidney’s inability to respond to parathyroid hormone appropriately. 
❌                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↓  ↓ ↑:
Incorrect: Vitamin D deficiency is characterized by decreased calcium, decreased phosphate, and increased parathyroid hormone levels.
❌                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↓  ↓  ↓ :
Incorrect: These findings are not consistent with calcium, phosphorus, and parathyroid hormone homeostasis disorders. 
❌                   Ca2+                        PO43-                                 PTH  ↑  ↑  ↓ :
Incorrect: These findings are not consistent with calcium, phosphorus, or parathyroid hormone homeostasis disorders.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of an enlarging neck mass. The patient first noticed the mass several months ago but failed to visit a doctor until today, when her symptoms worsened. She states, “It's gotten so big, I’m having trouble breathing when going up or down stairs.” She also has dysphagia with both solids and liquids. Past medical history is unremarkable. She has a twenty-pack-year smoking history. Vital signs are within normal limits. A CT of the neck is demonstrated below.  Which of the following is the best treatment for this patient’s clinical condition?  


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents for evaluation of obstructive goiter, as evidenced by the large anterior neck mass encircling the trachea and esophagus in the CT image shown. The most appropriate management in a patient with a large goiter and associated dyspnea or dysphagia symptoms is a total thyroidectomy.   

Goiter refers to an abnormal enlargement of the thyroid gland and has multiple etiologies, including thyroid malignancy, multinodular goiter, Hashimoto thyroiditis, Graves disease, and subclinical hyperthyroidism. Regardless of the etiology, an enlarging thyroid can result in a mass effect on adjacent structures resulting in obstructive symptoms. The thyroid gland most commonly grows outward because of its location in the anterior neck; however, bilateral lobar enlargement can extend posteriorly to the trachea–compressing the airway, esophagus, and surrounding blood vessels.  

Ultimately, this mass effect can result in dyspnea (the most common symptom), dysphagia, and hemorrhage into the goiter. In patients with symptomatic obstructive goiter, the most appropriate treatment is the complete surgical removal of the thyroid gland.   

Option Analysis

✅ Total thyroidectomy :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Subtotal thyroidectomy:
Incorrect: A subtotal thyroidectomy refers to partial or incomplete removal of the thyroid gland. This procedure is indicated in select cases for unilateral thyroid nodules. Removal of only a portion of the thyroid increases the risk for recurrent obstructive goiter or missed malignancy. 
❌ Radioactive iodine:
Incorrect: Surgery is the standard therapy for large goiters. Radioactive iodine is considered in cases of thyroid malignancy, hyperthyroidism or as an alternative for patients with large goiters who are not surgical candidates. Radioactive iodine therapy can also be considered in cases of nontoxic multinodular goiter, but it is only associated with a moderate reduction in thyroid volume. 
❌ Repeat CT-scan in one year :
Incorrect: Asymptomatic patients with normal flow-volume loops and whose goiters end at the level of the brachiocephalic vein or higher may elect to have serial CT scans. However, this patient presents with symptoms of airway obstruction and dysphagia, which should be addressed in a timely fashion.
❌ Recombinant human TSH:
Incorrect: Recombinant human TSH is a poorly studied therapy reserved for patients with obstructive goiter who are not surgical candidates.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman undergoes a total thyroidectomy due to the presence of follicular thyroid cancer. On a postoperative day one, the patient develops a hoarse, breathy voice. Vital signs are within normal limits, and physical examination demonstrates an intact postoperative incision without erythema or edema over the anterior neck. Which of the following structures was most likely injured intraoperatively?
questions.solution:
Several structures are at risk of iatrogenic injury in patients undergoing thyroidectomy and hemithyroidectomy. One of the structures at risk of injury is the recurrent laryngeal nerve (RLN).  Unilateral injury presents as temporary or permanent hoarseness and risk of aspiration (especially with liquids). In contrast, bilateral injury causes stridor and acute airway obstruction as the recurrent laryngeal nerve supplies the only abductor of the vocal cords, the posterior cricoarytenoid muscle.  The paired recurrent laryngeal nerves branch off the vagus nerve and travel in the tracheoesophageal groove until they enter the larynx at the cricothyroid joint. The RLN supplies innervation to all of the intrinsic muscles of the larynx, minus the cricothyroid muscles, as well as sensation to the larynx below the level of the vocal cords.

In addition to the RLN, several additional structures are at risk of injury during thyroidectomy, including the parathyroid glands, superior laryngeal nerve (SLN), vagus nerve, thyroid ima artery, and common carotid arteries (and their local branches). Injury to the vascular structures often results in hematoma/seroma formation and brisk bleeding intraoperatively. Injury to the SLN manifests as vocal fatigue and subtle changes in voice quality, pitch, and projection (in contrast to true hoarseness with RLN injury). Injury to the vagus nerve may result in the larynx's sensory and motor deficits.

Option Analysis

✅ Recurrent laryngeal nerve:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Superior laryngeal nerve:
Incorrect: Isolated superior laryngeal nerve injury only produces vocal fatigue and subtle changes in voice quality involving timbre, pitch, and voice projection. This patient presents with vocal cord paralysis.  
❌ Thyroid ima artery:
Incorrect: The thyroid ima artery is an unpaired, variable branch of the brachiocephalic artery that supplies the thyroid and the isthmus. When injured during head and neck procedures, it can be a source of brisk and difficult to control bleeding.  
❌ Common carotid artery:
Incorrect: Injury to the common carotid artery results in hematoma formation and possible neurologic deficits secondary to ischemic or thromboembolic events.  
❌ Vagus nerve:
Incorrect: Injury to the vagus nerve may result in paralysis of both the superior laryngeal nerve and the recurrent branch of the laryngeal nerve. This can result in both sensory and motor deficits of the larynx. Injury to the main trunk of the vagus nerve is rare during thyroid surgery.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents to the clinic for evaluation of a thyroid nodule that was found on chest imaging performed for lung cancer screening two weeks ago. She has no pain, dysphagia, or symptoms of thyroid dysfunction. She has a 25-pack-year smoking history and stopped smoking two years ago. Her medical history is unremarkable for thyroid disorders, irradiation, or surgery. There is no family history of thyroid disorders or syndromes. Temperature is 36.6 °C (97.9 °F), pulse is 82/min, respiratory rate is 15/min, blood pressure is 127/77 mmHg, and BMI is 41. Her skin is warm and dry. On physical examination, there are no palpable thyroid masses and no cervical lymphadenopathy. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Laboratory testing shows a serum thyroid-stimulating hormone level of 3.4 µU/L. Ultrasonography demonstrates a 1-cm hypoechoic mass with microcalcifications in the left lobe of the thyroid. What is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Surgical resection of the thyroid gland

questions.solution:
This patient has an asymptomatic and nonpalpable thyroid nodule found incidentally on unrelated imaging. Her thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level is within reference range, so the nodule is not producing thyroid hormone and is therefore a non-functioning thyroid nodule. Ultrasound shows a 1-cm hypoechoic mass with microcalcifications, characteristics with an intermediate to high suspicion for malignancy. In this situation, it is necessary to order a fine needle aspiration (FNA) of the nodule for cytological analysis.    

The initial evaluation of a patient with an incidental thyroid nodule (ITN) involves obtaining a history with an emphasis on thyroid-related concerns, including medications, symptoms of hypothyroidism or hyperthyroidism, and risk factors for thyroid malignancy. Physical examination should include a thorough examination of the neck and lymph nodes. Initial workup should include measuring serum TSH and performing a dedicated ultrasound of the thyroid and neck.      

If TSH is high or within reference range, the patient is hypothyroid or euthyroid, indicating a non-functioning nodule. If TSH is low, the patient is hyperthyroid and requires a radioactive iodine uptake (RAIU) scan to determine whether the nodule is hypofunctioning (“cold”) or hyperfunctioning (“hot”). When RAIU shows a solitary focus of uptake or patchy uptake that is concordant, or consistent, with ultrasound findings, then treatment of hyperthyroidism is indicated.    

However, patients with a non-functioning, hypofunctioning, or nonconcordant hyperfunctioning nodule should undergo FNA and cytology if ultrasound shows features suggestive of malignancy and the lesion is > or equal to 1 cm, as illustrated in the image below. Nodules with a low suspicion of malignancy should be biopsied when they measure ≥ 1.5 cm. If they are smaller, they can be followed up with a repeat ultrasound after 12–24 months.  



Option Analysis

✅ Fine-needle aspiration and cytology:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Repeat ultrasound in 12 to 24 months:
Incorrect: Waiting to obtain a repeat ultrasound would only be appropriate if a hypothyroid or euthyroid nodule, as seen in this case, has ultrasound findings, such as a cystic mass that is < 1 cm, that is likely benign. This patient has microcalcifications seen on ultrasound which raise suspicion for malignancy.
❌ Radioactive iodine uptake scan:
Incorrect: A radioactive iodine uptake (or RAIU) scan would be ordered only if the patient is hyperthyroid. This patient is euthyroid, both clinically and by laboratory testing of TSH.
❌ Surgical resection of the thyroid gland:
Incorrect: While this patient’s thyroid nodule is suspicious of malignancy, a biopsy would be required for cytological analysis before surgical treatment.  
❌ Repeat ultrasound within 6 months:
Incorrect: This nodule is 1 cm in diameter and has several ultrasound findings that are suspicious of malignancy. It would not be appropriate to wait instead of proceeding with further evaluation.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a three-month history of voice hoarseness and difficulty swallowing. She has no significant past medical history and takes a daily oral contraceptive pill. Temperature is 37°C (98.7°F), pulse is 73/min, and blood pressure is 118/73 mmHg. BMI is 38.6 kg/m<sup>2</sup>. Physical examination reveals a palpable, solitary, immobile anterior neck mass. TSH is within normal limits. Ultrasound of the neck reveals a solid lesion measuring 1.39 cm in diameter with irregular margins. Ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration reveals malignant cells and histology shows multiple finger-like projections or papillae with fibrovascular cores lined with differentiated epithelial cells with clear nuclei with intracytoplasmic inclusions that appear as holes. Which of the following types of thyroid cancer does this patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
This patient’s history and clinical presentation of hoarseness, dysphagia, a new neck mass, and a normal TSH is suggestive of thyroid carcinoma. Ultrasound-guided fine needle aspiration (FNA) shows malignant cells and histology demonstrating papillae lined with differentiated epithelial cells with pale nuclei with the appearance of “holes” secondary to intracytoplasmic inclusions (Orphan Annie-Eye Nuclei), which is pathognomonic for papillary carcinoma. Calcified psammoma bodies, which represent scarred remnants of tumor papillae that have likely infarcted, may also be seen in papillary carcinoma.

Evaluation of a palpable neck mass that is suspicious for thyroid malignancy includes TSH and  ultrasound. Malignant thyroid lesions seen on ultrasound typically are larger than 1 cm in diameter with microcalcifications, hypervascularity, and irregular margins. Cystic lesions that are < 1cm in diameter are not consistent with thyroid cancer.  

Following the diagnosis of papillary carcinoma, cancer staging using the TNM staging system (Tumor size, Node involvement, Metastasis) and a CT scan should be performed to determine the appropriate treatment.
