Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 2-week-old male is brought to the emergency department by his parents for jaundice and hypotonia. He was born at 39 weeks gestation via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The patient was jaundiced at birth, and the symptoms have persisted. He is exclusively breastfed and produces 6-7 wet diapers per day. Family history is notable for hypertension in his father. Physical examination shows jaundice and reduced muscle tone throughout the body. In addition, the patient has scleral icterus and impaired upward gaze in the left eye. Laboratory testing reveals the following findings:  
 
Laboratory value  Result 
 Hemoglobin  16.5 mg/dL 
 Hematocrit  49.5% 
 Mean corpuscular hemoglobin  27.8 pg/cell 
 Leukocyte count  7,100/mm3 
 Total bilirubin  23.0 mg/dL 
 Conjugated bilirubin  0.3 mg/dL 
Which of the following interventions will provide definitive treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I, a congenital condition characterized by the absence of UDP-glucuronyl transferase (UDPGT) activity. Therefore, affected individuals cannot conjugate bilirubin at all. This deficiency ultimately leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, with a very high total bilirubin levels that can range from 20-50 mg/dL.  

Patients with Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I typically develop symptoms soon after birth. These symptoms include persistent neonatal jaundice and kernicterus, which can cause neurological deficits ranging from hypotonia to extraocular palsy.

Temporizing treatment to bring down bilirubin levels include plasmapheresis and phototherapy. Plasmapheresis removes albumin and any bound bilirubin. Phototherapy works by increasing the polarity and water solubility of unconjugated bilirubin, hence allowing it to be excreted via urine. However, the only definitive treatment for Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I is liver transplantation.  

Option Analysis

❌ Administration of phenobarbital:
Incorrect: Phenobarbital is used to treat Crigler-Najjar syndrome type II, a condition characterized by reduced UDP-glucuronosyltransferase (UDPGT) activity. The medication increases UDPGT activity, thus reducing unconjugated bilirubin levels. However, phenobarbital is not effective in managing Crigler-Najjar syndrome type I, in which there is no UDPGT to stimulate.
❌ Initiation of plasmapheresis:
Incorrect: Plasmapheresis is an intervention that can temporarily reduce serum bilirubin levels. This therapy works because unconjugated bilirubin is bound to albumin, which is removed by plasmapheresis. However, plasmapheresis does not provide definitive treatment for this patient’s condition.
✅ Liver transplantation:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Initiation of phototherapy  :
Incorrect: Phototherapy increases the polarity and water solubility of unconjugated bilirubin. This therapy helps increase the unconjugated bilirubin’s excretion from the body. However, phototherapy is only a temporizing measure for Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1, and patients will ultimately need a liver transplant.
❌ Surgical splenectomy:
Incorrect: Hereditary spherocytosis can cause increased hemolysis and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. Splenectomy can provide definitive treatment for this condition. However, patients with hereditary spherocytosis will likely have laboratory findings showing anemia, increased mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration, and increased reticulocyte count. In contrast, this patient has none of the aforementioned findings.

questions.text: A 4-day-old girl is evaluated in the nursery for failure to pass meconium and abdominal distention. The patient was born at 40-weeks gestational age to a 35-year-old, gravida 2 para 2, mother via spontaneous vaginal delivery. She is breastfeeding well but has not yet passed meconium. Physical examination is notable for upslanted palpebral fissures, prominent epicanthal folds, and a distended abdomen. Digital rectal exam is performed, causing large quantities of gas and stool to be expelled across the room. Which of the following would be most useful in providing a definitive diagnosis for this patient’s current condition?
questions.solution:
This patient has Hirschsprung disease (also termed congenital aganglionic megacolon), which occurs due to the defective migration of neural crest cells to the distal colon. As a result, affected segments of the colon lack the Meissner and Auerbach plexus, which are responsible for controlling smooth muscle contraction and relaxation. The condition is associated with Down syndrome and RET gene mutations.    

Patients with Hirschsprung disease typically fail to pass the meconium within the first two days after birth. In addition, since the rectum is affected, feces builds up in the more proximal sections of the bowel. This accumulation results in serious constipation, abdominal distention, and toxic megacolon, which is a risk for rupture. Digital rectal exam will reveal a tight anal sphincter and will trigger the explosive release of feces.  

Diagnosis is made via rectal suction biopsy of the mucosa and submucosa, which reveals the lack of ganglion cells. Treatment is surgical resection of the aganglionic section of the intestine.
   

Option Analysis

❌ Barium enema :
Incorrect: In patients with Hirschsprung disease, a barium enema may reveal narrowing of the rectum and sigmoid colon. However, a rectal suction biopsy is nonetheless needed to confirm the diagnosis. 
❌ Abdominal x-ray :
Incorrect: An abdominal x-ray can show distention of the proximal colon in Hirschsprung disease. However, this test would be insufficient to distinguish Hirschsprung disease from etiologies (e.g., volvulus, intussusception) that can cause intestinal obstruction and distention. 
❌ Technetium-99 uptake scan :
Incorrect: A technetium-99 scan can identify areas of heterotopic gastric mucosa and be used to diagnose patients with Meckel diverticulum. Patients with Meckel diverticulum can have abdominal pain and bloody stools. However, it would be atypical for a Meckel diverticulum to present with abdominal distention or an explosive release of feces after digital rectal exam. 
✅ Rectal suction biopsy :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌  Chromosome analysis :
Incorrect: This patient’s facial features are consistent with Down syndrome, which can be confirmed via chromosomal analysis. However, the patient’s constipation and abdominal distention are most likely due to Hirschsprung disease, a condition associated with Down syndrome. A biopsy showing the absence of ganglion cells in the rectum is necessary to diagnose a patient with Hirschsprung disease.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician due to several months of recurrent episodes of bloating and diarrhea that are worse after eating. He has also unintentionally lost 6 lbs (2.7 kg) over this same time. Several weeks ago, he developed a pruritic rash on the bilateral forearms. One year ago, he was hospitalized after a motor vehicle accident and experienced an episode of anaphylactic shock after receiving a blood transfusion. He has no recent history of travel. Physical examination shows conjunctival pallor. There are multiple tense, grouped subepidermal blisters on the elbows and dorsal forearms bilaterally. There is also mild tenderness to palpation throughout the abdomen. Laboratory studies from his previous hospitalization are shown below. Which of the following diagnostic studies is the most appropriate next step?

Immunoglobulins, serum
IgA
<5 mg/dL (low)
IgG
1200 mg/dL (normal)
IgM
325 mg/dL (normal)
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of celiac disease (bloating, diarrhea, weight loss, dermatitis herpetiformis) and likely has selective IgA deficiency as well. IgG-based testing with deamidated gliadin peptide (DGP)-IgG should be performed next.

Celiac disease is associated with selective IgA deficiency, and this likely explains the prior episode of anaphylaxis after receiving blood products. Normally, tissue transglutaminase (tTG)-IgA antibody is the preferred test for detection of celiac disease. However, in patients with IgA deficiency, IgG-based testing with deamidated gliadin peptide (DGP)-IgG is commonly performed to prevent false negative results. If the anti–deamidated gliadin peptide IgG antibody level is elevated, upper endoscopy with duodenal biopsy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and the severity. The presence of villus atrophy indicates a diagnosis of celiac disease, for which a gluten-free diet should be prescribed.

Option Analysis

❌ IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies:
Incorrect: IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase is often the preferred diagnostic test for celiac disease. However, based on prior bloodwork, this patient likely has selective IgA deficiency, and therefore testing for IgA anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies would likely result in a false negative result.
❌ Stool for ova and parasites:
Incorrect: Testing the stool for ova and parasites is an appropriate initial diagnostic tool for patients presenting with diarrhea. However, this patient has not traveled recently, and his dermatitis herpetiformis and selective IgA deficiency which are more indicative of celiac disease.
✅ Anti–deamidated gliadin peptide IgG antibodies:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Fecal elastase:
Incorrect: Fecal elastase is a screening test for patients suspected of having pancreatic insufficiency. Although this patient may have steatorrhea, he lacks the risk factors associated with pancreatic insufficiency (e.g., alcohol abuse, and recurrent episodes of pancreatitis).
❌ Hydrogen breath test:
Incorrect: A hydrogen breath test is a screening tool for patients suspected of having lactose intolerance. Although this patient is presenting with episodes of bloating and diarrhea after eating, he has other clinical and laboratory findings that are not consistent with lactose intolerance alone.

questions.text: A newborn boy is delivered at 36 weeks' gestation via emergency cesarean section for fetal heart rate decelerations. The mother had no prenatal care and reported frequent tobacco use during pregnancy. There was no history of fever, recent illness, or substance use other than tobacco. Rupture of membranes occurred at the time of delivery. The delivery proceeded without complication, and Apgar scores are 6 and 8 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 130/min, respirations are 35/min, blood pressure is 69/36 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, a full-thickness abdominal wall defect is noted to the right of the umbilicus with herniated bowel and no associated sac. The remainder of the examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This newborn has findings consistent with gastroschisis, a full-thickness abdominal wall defect with herniated bowel and no associated sac. The next best step in management is the placement of a nasogastric tube to decompress the stomach.       

Gastroschisis is a congenital abdominal wall defect associated with evisceration of the bowel. Prenatal screening may reveal an elevated alpha-fetoprotein level, and ultrasound often identifies the abdominal wall defect. Risk factors include young maternal age, tobacco use, and use of illicit drugs during pregnancy. On physical examination, gastroschisis typically presents as herniation of abdominal contents through a defect to the right of the umbilicus without a covering membrane. Herniated contents commonly include the small intestine, and intestinal atresia may be present. The most frequent complication is gastrointestinal dysmotility.        
All newborns with abdominal wall defects should undergo an ABCDE assessment. If the patient is unstable, the priority is to stabilize airway, breathing, and circulation. In stable patients, a nasogastric or orogastric tube should be placed for gastric decompression. The exposed abdominal contents should be covered with warm, moist, sterile gauze or a bowel bag to reduce the risk of fluid loss, infection, and ischemia. Intravenous access should be established to initiate total parenteral nutrition soon after birth. Once stabilized, the patient should receive continuous monitoring and supplemental oxygen as needed. Definitive treatment involves surgical closure of the defect.   

Option Analysis

❌ Genetics consultation :
Incorrect: While genetic consultation may be appropriate in some neonates with congenital anomalies, gastroschisis is typically an isolated defect not associated with chromosomal abnormalities. It is not part of the initial management. 
❌ Abdominal ultrasound :
Incorrect: Abdominal ultrasound should be performed in patients with gastroschisis; however, it does not take precedence over immediate stabilization measures.  
❌ Barium enema :
Incorrect: A barium enema is useful in the evaluation of conditions such as Hirschsprung disease, which typically presents with delayed passage of meconium and abdominal distention. It has no role in the diagnosis or management of gastroschisis.  
✅ Nasogastric tube placement :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Intravenous inotrope therapy  :
Incorrect: Inotrope therapy is reserved for patients with signs of hemodynamic instability. Although the blood pressure in this vignette may appear low, it is within the normal range for a newborn at 36 weeks’ gestation. Given the infant's stable perfusion and vital signs, inotropes are not indicated yet.

questions.text: A 4-week-old girl is evaluated during a well-check visit. The infant was born at term via an uncomplicated vaginal delivery and had an unremarkable neonatal course. A caregiver reports noticing an abdominal mass after the umbilical cord separated. There is no fever, vomiting, or diarrhea. Urine output and bowel movements are normal. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 129/min, respirations are 38/min, blood pressure is 75/41 mm Hg, and oxygen saturation is 96% on room air. Physical examination reveals no rash, a supple neck, and a normal cranial exam. Capillary refill is less than 2 seconds. Cardiopulmonary examination is unremarkable. The abdomen is soft and nontender with a reducible umbilical mass. No drainage is noted on exam. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This infant presents with a non-tender, reducible umbilical mass without drainage, consistent with an umbilical hernia.       

All infants with an umbilical mass should be evaluated for the presence and quality of any associated drainage. An umbilical hernia is more likely when no drainage is present. If drainage is observed, its characteristics can help identify the underlying cause. Clear urine suggests a patent urachus, while feculent or brown discharge may indicate an omphalomesenteric fistula. When such conditions are suspected, an abdominal ultrasound is typically performed for further evaluation.       

Umbilical hernias are common in newborns and result from incomplete closure of the umbilical ring fascia, allowing protrusion of intra-abdominal contents. They present as soft, non-tender, reducible midline masses that may become more prominent with crying, coughing, or straining. Asymptomatic hernias often close spontaneously by age 2. However, the development of abdominal pain or vomiting may indicate strangulation, which requires urgent surgical intervention.   

Option Analysis

❌ Gastroschisis  :
Incorrect: Gastroschisis is an abdominal wall defect present at birth with herniation of abdominal contents through an opening typically to the right of the umbilicus. The bowel is exposed without a protective sac, and the viscera are not reducible. The findings in this case are more consistent with an umbilical hernia.  
❌ Omphalomesenteric fistula. :
Incorrect: An omphalomesenteric fistula results from a persistent connection between the intestinal tract and the umbilicus. It typically presents with continuous feculent drainage, not as a reducible mass. The findings in this case are more consistent with an umbilical hernia. 
❌ Patent urachus :
Incorrect: A patent urachus is a persistent connection between the bladder and the umbilicus. It usually presents with clear urinary discharge from the umbilicus rather than a reducible mass. The findings in this case are more consistent with an umbilical hernia. 
❌ Umbilical granuloma  :
Incorrect: An umbilical granuloma appears as moist, red granulation tissue at the base of the umbilicus after cord separation. It may produce serosanguinous or yellow drainage but does not present as a reducible mass. The findings in this case are more consistent with an umbilical hernia. 
✅ Umbilical hernia :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: An 11-year-old girl is brought to the pediatrician by her parents who are concerned about recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and bloating and episodes of diarrhea alternating with constipation. Her parents also report that she has become increasingly irritable and has not been gaining weight or growing as expected. The mother has a history of Sjögren syndrome and hypothyroidism. Temperature is 37.0 ºC (98.6 °F), heart rate is 84/min, respiratory rate is 16/min, and blood pressure is 115/70 mmHg. Body-mass index is in the 5th percentile. On physical exam, the abdomen is mildly tender to palpation throughout. Bloodwork shows iron deficiency anemia. Which of the following additional physical examination findings would be consistent with the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Light-brown skin spots on bilateral upper extremities
Erythematous scaly plaques on the scalp
Tense, grouped subepidermal blisters on the bilateral forearms

questions.solution:
This patient's clinical presentation of intermittent abdominal pain and bloating, alternating episodes of diarrhea, constipation associated with iron deficiency anemia, and failure to meet growth and weight expectations is consistent with celiac disease, which is associated with dermatitis herpetiformis, a skin manifestation of the condition. Dermatitis herpetiformis is characterized by pruritic, blistering lesions that typically affect extensor surfaces like the elbows, knees, and buttocks, but can also be found on the forearms.

Celiac disease typically presents with a combination of gastrointestinal and extraintestinal symptoms that develop after the introduction of gluten into the diet. Historical findings may include chronic diarrhea, abdominal pain, bloating, and steatorrhea, often leading to weight loss or failure to thrive in children. Patients may also report fatigue, which could be a consequence of malabsorption of nutrients like iron, leading to anemia. On physical examination, there may be signs of malnutrition including muscle wasting, short stature, and delayed puberty. Dermatological findings can include dermatitis herpetiformis. Additionally, dental enamel hypoplasia and aphthous ulcers may be present. The presence of a personal or family history of autoimmune diseases (e.g. Sjögren syndrome) can further support the suspicion of celiac disease.


Option Analysis

❌ Light-brown skin spots on bilateral upper extremities:
Incorrect: Cafe-au-lait macules are light brown skin spots that are commonly associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 and other genetic conditions, not celiac disease which is the most likely diagnosis in this patient.
❌ Erythematous scaly plaques on the scalp:
Incorrect: Erythematous scaly plaques on the scalp are more characteristic of psoriasis, an autoimmune skin condition that is not directly associated with celiac disease.
✅ Tense, grouped subepidermal blisters on the bilateral forearms:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Telangiectasia on the oral mucosa:
Incorrect: Telangiectasias are a hallmark of hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia (Osler-Weber-Rendu syndrome). They are not associated with the most likely diagnosis in this patient which is celiac disease.
❌ Yellowish plaques on the eyelids:
Incorrect: Xanthelasmas are yellowish plaques that represent deposits of cholesterol under the skin. These are associated with hyperlipidemia, not celiac disease.

questions.text:
A 3-day-old boy is evaluated by the pediatric hospitalist after an uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The patient was born at 38 weeks gestation. There were no known complications during the pregnancy or delivery. However, there was limited prenatal care. Examination at delivery was notable for upslanting palpebral fissures, a flat-nasal bridge, and a protruding tongue. The patient has not yet passed meconium. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination demonstrates a well-appearing infant in no acute distress. Head and neck examination are unchanged from birth. The abdomen is soft but distended. Lower abdominal fullness is present. Digital rectal examination results in an explosive expulsion of gas and liquid stool. An abdominal X-ray is obtained and seen below. Which of the following would confirm this patient’s diagnosis? 
 
 
Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

choices.text: Contrast enema with rectal suction biopsy
Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the abdomen and lumbar spine
Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and thyroxine (T4) levels
Tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A (tTG IgA) levels

questions.solution:
This 3-day-old neonate presents with failure to pass meconium within 48 hours of delivery. Moreover, this patient has evidence of trisomy 21 facies and an abdominal radiograph demonstrating dilated proximal bowel loops with decreased air in the distal segment of the intestines, consistent with Hirschsprung disease. Patients with suspicion for this disease should undergo further confirmatory testing with contrast enema with rectal suction biopsy. Biopsy results will show evidence of the aganglionic colonic segment.

Newborn patients with constipation should be assessed regarding the timing of meconium passage. Newborns with delayed passage of meconium (> 48 hours from delivery) are more likely to suffer from an obstruction. These patients should be assessed for the presence of an imperforate anus or intestinal obstruction. Patients with an obstruction will demonstrate evidence of dilated loops of bowel on radiographs. Patients with Hirschsprung disease will often have evidence of decreased or absent air in the distal segment of the intestines. In contrast, patients with meconium ileus will have evidence of a “bubbly appearance.” Confirmatory testing is achieved with a contrast enema, and if there is concern for Hirschsprung disease, rectal suction biopsy should be performed.

Newborns that have difficulty stooling after delivery (though not necessarily in the first 48 hours after delivery) should be assessed for possible spinal cord disorder. This may present as a deep sacral dimple, sacral tuft of hair, absent anal wink, or decreased lower extremity reflexes. If there is concern for a spinal cord abnormality, a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the spine should be obtained to assess for the presence of meningomyelocele, spinal cord tumor, or tethered cord.

Infants and children with constipation should be evaluated for medication or toxin exposure, and if absent, patients should be assessed for an organic etiology of constipation. Further workup and confirmatory testing is dependent upon clinical findings. For example, patients with fatigue, hair loss, or cold intolerance should be evaluated for endocrinopathies, such as hypothyroidism, by evaluating the thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and free thyroxine (T4). Celiac disease should be considered when appropriate risk factors are present (e.g. history of autoimmune disease) or typical findings are present (e.g. dermatitis herpetiformis). Confirmatory testing for this condition can be achieved via measurement of tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A (tTG IgA) and total IgA levels. Once organic etiologies have been considered and excluded, patients with constipation should be evaluated for irritable bowel syndrome and functional constipation. These are diagnoses of exclusion and are made using the Rome criteria.   

Option Analysis

✅ Contrast enema with rectal suction biopsy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) of the abdomen and lumbar spine:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms and physical examination are consistent with Hirschsprung disease and trisomy 21. When there is high suspicion for Hirschsprung, as in this case, a contrast enema with rectal suction biopsy is the best next step to confirm the diagnosis. An MRI would be indicated if there was concern for spinal cord abnormality (e.g. decreased reflexes or deep sacral dimple).  
❌ Thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) and thyroxine (T4) levels:
Incorrect: This patient’s symptoms, physical examination, and abdominal X-ray are consistent with Hirschsprung disease and trisomy 21. A contrast enema with rectal suction biopsy would confirm the diagnosis. TSH and T4 levels should be considered if there is concern for hypothyroidism as the cause of a patient’s constipation. Although hypothyroidism is associated with trisomy 21, it would not present with these abdominal X-ray findings, and it would be unusual to present in a neonate.  
❌ Tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A (tTG IgA) levels:
Incorrect: Patients with celiac disease can present with constipation and will often have an elevated tissue transglutaminase immunoglobulin A (tTG IgA) levels. However, this patient’s age, symptoms, physical examination, and abdominal X-ray are consistent with Hirschsprung disease and trisomy 21. A contrast enema with rectal suction biopsy would confirm the diagnosis.  
❌ Sweat test:
Incorrect: Cystic fibrosis can present with meconium ileus and can be diagnosed with a sweat test. Patients with meconium ileus can present similarly to patients with Hirschsprung disease but the X-ray results and trisomy 21 features in this clinical scenario makes Hirschsprung disease more likely. A contrast enema with rectal suction biopsy would confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 5-week-old boy is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of multiple episodes of non-bloody nonbilious projectile emesis. The parents report the patient has always spit up, but the volume, frequency, and intensity of spit-up has increased significantly over the past week, and it has become projectile. The patient immediately vomits after feeding and is always hungry. He has only gained 12 grams/day. He has an appropriate frequency of wet diapers. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 152/min, blood pressure is 78/48 mm Hg, respirations are 36/min, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. On physical examination, the anterior fontanelle is open and flat. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. The abdomen appears slightly distended and an “olive-like” mass is palpated in the upper right quadrant. Abdominal ultrasound confirms the presumed diagnosis by identifying a thickened pyloric sphincter (4mm). Which of the following is most strongly associated with this patient’s underlying condition?
questions.solution:
This 5-week-old boy presents to the emergency department with increasing frequency and intensity of vomiting. The patient has projectile emesis immediately after eating and always seems hungry. Physical examination is significant for an “olive-shaped” abdominal mass in the right upper quadrant, and abdominal ultrasound identifies a thickened pyloric sphincter. These findings are consistent with pyloric stenosis. The incidence of pyloric stenosis is increased in males and in firstborn children. The incidence is also increased in preterm infants and children born to younger mothers.        

When assessing newborns or infants who present with vomiting, the patient's age can help create a differential diagnosis, and it is important to determine if the emesis is bilious or nonbilious. If the vomiting is not bilious, the next step is to determine if it is projectile, as projectile nonbilious emesis is most often due to pyloric stenosis.        

Nonprojectile nonbilious emesis can be further differentiated based on whether the onset of symptoms is acute or gradual. Examples of acute onset, nonprojectile, nonbilious emesis include infections and food protein induced enterocolitis (FPIES). Examples of gradual onset, nonprojectile, nonbilious emesis include genetic disorders such as inborn errors of metabolism and congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH).      

Bilious emesis is often a sign of intestinal obstruction and is considered a surgical emergency in infants and newborns. Preterm newborns are at risk for developing necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). Other causes of bilious emesis not associated with prematurity include malrotation with volvulus and intussusception.   

Option Analysis

✅ Being the firstborn male:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Maternal age >35:
Incorrect: This patient is diagnosed with pyloric stenosis by abdominal ultrasound. The incidence of pyloric stenosis decreases as maternal age increases. The incidence of pyloric stenosis is highest in firstborn males. 
❌ Currant jelly stool:
Incorrect: Currant jelly stool is associated with intussusception. This patient is diagnosed with pyloric stenosis by abdominal ultrasound. The incidence of pyloric stenosis is highest in firstborn males.   
❌ Abnormal newborn screen:
Incorrect: Newborn screens can identify numerous genetic disorders that may lead to vomiting, including inborn errors of metabolism. This patient has pyloric stenosis, which is not a disorder diagnosed by newborn screening. The incidence of pyloric stenosis is increased in firstborn males. 
❌ Abnormal reflexes:
Incorrect: Patients with increased intracranial pressure can present with vomiting and abnormal reflexes. This patient has pyloric stenosis, which is not associated with abnormal reflexes. The incidence of Pyloric stenosis is increased in firstborn males.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with four months of intermittent abdominal pain, bloating, and diarrhea. His mother notes that the symptoms seem to worsen after meals, which are typically well-balanced with dairy, vegetables, grains, and meat. He has also been experiencing significant weight loss and fatigue. The patient traveled to India eight months ago. Family history is notable for type 1 diabetes in his mother and an aunt with hypothyroidism. Vitals are within normal limits. His growth chart shows a drop from the 50<sup>th</sup> to the 25<sup>th</sup> percentile over the past six months. On physical exam, there is no abdominal tenderness to palpation. Laboratory results show microcytic anemia and positive anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. Which of the following is the best next step in management?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of celiac disease (diarrhea, weight loss, microcytic anemia) which is confirmed by the anti-tissue transglutaminase antibodies. Treatment should be centered around lifelong avoidance of gluten-containing products.

Given the complexity and potential expense of maintaining a gluten-free diet, it is essential to refer all patients to a dietitian. A dietitian can provide comprehensive guidance on identifying and avoiding gluten sources and ensuring the diet meets the nutritional requirements appropriate for the patient's age, including adequate intake of calcium, vitamin D, and other essential nutrients. If a patient exhibits a suboptimal response to the dietary changes it may be indicative of inadvertent gluten consumption. In such instances, the dietitian should conduct a thorough review of the patient's dietary habits. Furthermore, all patients should take a daily multivitamin supplement, and pediatric patients may require additional caloric supplementation to support optimal growth.

In addition to nutritional support, it is important to assess quality of life and address any psychosocial impacts stemming from the dietary restrictions imposed by celiac disease. Children in particular may face challenges such as bullying at school or feeling left out during social activities where gluten-containing foods are prevalent.

Option Analysis

❌ Avoidance of dairy products:
Incorrect: While dairy product avoidance may be recommended for temporary lactose intolerance secondary to intestinal damage in celiac disease, it is not the definitive treatment for celiac disease itself.
❌ Five day course of metronidazole:
Incorrect: Metronidazole is an antibiotic used to treat infections such as giardiasis, but it would not address the autoimmune process underlying celiac disease, which is the likely cause of his symptoms, not infectious colitis from travel.
✅ Lifelong gluten avoidance:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Tumor necrosis factor (TNF)-alpha inhibitor initiation:
Incorrect: TNF-alpha inhibitors are used to treat certain inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis and inflammatory bowel disease, but they are not a treatment for celiac disease.
❌ Pancreatic enzyme replacement therapy:
Incorrect: This therapy is used in conditions such as cystic fibrosis or chronic pancreatitis where pancreatic enzyme production is insufficient, which is not the case in celiac disease.

questions.text: A biologically male newborn delivered at 39 weeks’ gestation is evaluated in the delivery room for an unusual appearance of the abdomen. There is a history of poor prenatal care and consanguineous marriage. There is no history of drug use or febrile illness with rash during pregnancy. Apgar scores were 7 and 9 at 1 and 5 minutes, respectively. Delivery was otherwise uneventful. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 135/min, respirations are 37/min, blood pressure is 66/37 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 98% on room air. On examination, the infant appears hypotonic. Abdominal examination reveals thin, wrinkled abdominal wall skin and visible peristalsis with palpable kidneys and bladder. Examination is otherwise unremarkable. Which of the following physical exam findings would help confirm the patient’s most likely underlying diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This newborn presents with a history of poor prenatal care and exam findings of a thin, wrinkled abdominal wall with visible peristalsis and palpable kidneys and bladder. Together, these findings suggest prune belly syndrome. Undescended testes are expected on physical exam.       

Newborns with abdominal wall abnormalities should be assessed for muscle tone and the appearance of the overlying skin. Decreased muscle tone and wrinkled skin are characteristic of prune belly syndrome. If abdominal tone and skin appear normal, the next step is to evaluate for the presence of an umbilical or inguinal mass and assess for drainage. A non-draining mass is more likely to represent a hernia, while drainage may indicate a patent urachus (if urine) or an omphalomesenteric fistula (if feculent). Abdominal wall defects with exposed viscera suggest either gastroschisis or omphalocele.       

Prune belly syndrome, also known as Eagle-Barrett syndrome, is a congenital disorder characterized by a triad of abdominal muscle deficiency, urinary tract malformations, and bilateral cryptorchidism in biological males. Prenatal history may include oligohydramnios, bladder distension, or dilation of the ureters or kidneys on ultrasound. On physical exam, the hallmark is a wrinkled abdominal wall due to partial or complete absence of abdominal musculature. A distended, palpable bladder and undescended testes are also commonly noted. To help confirm the diagnosis, chest and abdominal radiographs, a voiding cystourethrogram, and an echocardiogram should be obtained.   

Option Analysis

❌ Hemihypertrophy  :
Incorrect: Hemihypertrophy refers to asymmetric overgrowth of one side of the body and may be seen in syndromes such as Beckwith-Wiedemann, which can also include omphalocele. The findings described in this case are more consistent with prune belly syndrome, which is characterized by abdominal wall laxity, urinary tract anomalies, and undescended testes. 
❌ Meconium-stained umbilicus  :
Incorrect: A meconium-stained umbilicus suggests an omphalomesenteric fistula, which typically presents with feculent discharge from the umbilicus. The findings described in this case are more consistent with prune belly syndrome, which is characterized by abdominal wall laxity, urinary tract anomalies, and undescended testes. 
❌ Umbilical granulation tissue :
Incorrect: An umbilical granuloma appears as moist, red granulation tissue at the base of the umbilicus after the cord separates. It is not associated with prune belly syndrome. 
✅ Undescended testes  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Silk glove sign  :
Incorrect: The silk glove sign refers to a smooth sensation on palpation of the thickened processus vaginalis, often seen in an inguinal hernia. It is not associated with prune belly syndrome.

questions.text: A newborn male delivered at 38 weeks’ gestation is evaluated in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU). The infant was born to a primigravida mother. Prenatal ultrasonography demonstrated an abdominal wall defect, and the pregnancy was complicated by oligohydramnios. There is no history of maternal fever or substance use. Delivery was uneventful. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 160/min, respirations are 37/min, blood pressure is 65/35 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. On physical examination, there is an abdominal wall defect at the umbilicus with a herniated small intestine in a fluid-filled sac. Pediatric surgery and genetics are consulted. Which of the following diagnostic tests is indicated?
questions.solution:
This newborn presents with a midline abdominal wall defect and herniated small intestine contained within a fluid-filled sac, consistent with an omphalocele. Given the high incidence of associated cardiopulmonary anomalies, an echocardiogram is indicated.       

Omphalocele is an abdominal wall defect in which herniated viscera are enclosed in a membranous sac composed of peritoneum, Wharton’s jelly, and amnion. It is frequently associated with other congenital anomalies, including cardiac, genitourinary, and neural tube defects. On physical examination, a midline abdominal wall defect is typically observed, with a sac that may contain a small bowel, stomach, colon, bladder, or liver. Omphalocele should be differentiated from gastroschisis, where the herniated bowel is usually located to the right of the umbilicus and is not covered by a protective membrane, leaving it exposed to amniotic fluid.       

Newborns with abdominal wall defects should be evaluated for associated anomalies. Unlike gastroschisis, which is usually an isolated defect, omphalocele is often part of a broader syndrome. Genetic testing should be performed to assess for chromosomal abnormalities such as trisomy 13, 18, or 21, and Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome. Renal ultrasonography and echocardiography are recommended to screen for genitourinary and cardiac anomalies, respectively.   

Option Analysis

❌ Barium enema :
Incorrect: A barium enema is used to evaluate Hirschsprung disease, which typically presents with delayed passage of meconium and abdominal distention. This infant’s findings are more consistent with an omphalocele, and an echocardiogram is indicated to evaluate for associated cardiopulmonary anomalies. 
❌ Blood culture  :
Incorrect: Blood cultures are indicated when neonatal sepsis is suspected, typically in the presence of temperature instability, respiratory distress, lethargy, or hemodynamic compromise. This infant’s findings are more consistent with an omphalocele, and an echocardiogram is indicated to evaluate for associated cardiopulmonary anomalies. 
❌ Chest X-ray :
Incorrect: A chest X-ray is helpful in evaluating congenital diaphragmatic hernia, which presents with respiratory distress, a scaphoid abdomen, and possible bowel sounds in the chest. This infant’s findings are more consistent with an omphalocele, and an echocardiogram is indicated to evaluate for associated cardiopulmonary anomalies. 
✅ Echocardiogram  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Voiding cystourethrogram :
Incorrect: A voiding cystourethrogram is indicated for patients with prune belly syndrome to evaluate for associated ureteral reflux and dilatation. This infant’s findings are more consistent with an omphalocele, and an echocardiogram is indicated to evaluate for associated cardiopulmonary anomalies.

questions.text: A 3-week-old girl presents to the pediatrician’s office with new-onset post-prandial vomiting. She and her monozygotic twin sister were born via spontaneous vaginal delivery at 36 weeks without complications. Both twins received pertussis prophylaxis before discharge as their school-aged sibling at home was being treated for pertussis. Family history is significant for ulcerative colitis in their father and asthma in their sibling. Her mother reports that the patient has been afebrile without coughing or breathing difficulties at home. She has been exclusively breastfed since birth. However, over the last 1-2 days she has vomited after each feeding. Her mother reports that the vomit is white in color and is very forceful. She notes that the infant continues to want to feed despite recurrent emesis. Physical exam demonstrates dry mucous membranes and capillary refill in 4 seconds. Abdominal exam is unremarkable. Which of the following elements of this patient’s history is most likely associated with the current condition?
questions.solution:
In this 3-week-old girl with new-onset vomiting that is postprandial, non-bilious, and forceful, pyloric stenosis should be suspected. Pertussis prophylaxis was given, which should increase suspicion of pyloric stenosis as macrolide exposure within the first 2 weeks of life (macrolides are the treatment of choice for pertussis prophylaxis in neonates) increases the risk of pyloric stenosis.

Patients with pyloric stenosis are typically between 2 and 6 weeks of age with recurrent episodes of immediate, forceful, postprandial vomiting. Infants with pyloric stenosis are often called “hungry vomiters,” as they are persistently hungry despite episodes of postprandial emesis. They also may have poor weight gain and fewer wet diapers consistent with dehydration from poor oral intake. Additionally, patients might have risk factors for pyloric stenosis, such as preterm birth, family history of pyloric stenosis, macrolide use within the first 2 weeks of birth, maternal smoking, bottle feeding, and they may be first-born males. Physical exams may demonstrate signs of dehydration, such as dry mucous membranes or delayed capillary refill. Abdominal exam might reveal an olive-like mass in the right upper quadrant and even peristaltic waves moving across the abdomen. However, these findings are not always present, and their absence does not rule out pyloric stenosis.
 
 
Transverse ultrasound of pyloric stenosis shows a cross-sectional view of the thickened pylorus (“target sign”). The diameter is measured between the 1 calipers, and the single wall thickness is measured between the 2 calipers.  

Option Analysis

❌ Twin birth:
Incorrect: Twin births are not specifically associated with an increased risk of developing pyloric stenosis. However, premature birth, as seen in this patient who was born at 36 weeks, is associated with an increased risk of pyloric stenosis.  
✅ Pertussis prophylaxis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Family history of ulcerative colitis:
Incorrect: There is no known association between inflammatory bowel disease and pyloric stenosis.  
❌ Female sex:
Incorrect: Male infants, not female infants, are at an increased risk of developing pyloric stenosis.  
❌ Breastfeeding:
Incorrect: Bottle-feeding, not breastfeeding, is associated with an increased risk of pyloric stenosis. This patient has been exclusively breastfed since birth.

questions.text:

Since then, he has been feeding, voiding, and stooling normally. Over the last few days, however, he has developed projectile, non-bilious emesis after each feeding. His last wet diaper was approximately 12 hours ago. In the ED, his temperature is 36.2 °C (97.2 ºF), pulse is 172/min, respirations are 52/min, blood pressure is 62/25 mmHg, and SpO2 is 98%. On physical examination, the patient has a sunken anterior fontanelle, dry mucous membranes, and capillary refill in 6 seconds. choices.text: IV fluid resuscitation and IV electrolyte repletion

questions.solution:
This 5-week-old boy’s history of new-onset non-bilious, post-prandial, projectile vomiting, physical exam with signs of hypovolemia and a palpable round abdominal mass, and hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis, are consistent with pyloric stenosis. In this patient, initial assessment demonstrates hemodynamic instability (tachycardia and hypotension), so the next steps in management are to provide IV fluid resuscitation and IV electrolyte repletion.

Pyloric stenosis most commonly presents in patients between 2 and 6 weeks of age with forceful vomiting due to partial or complete gastric outlet obstruction. Oral intolerance and vomiting result in dehydration, which can range from mild to severe, sometimes even resulting in hypovolemic shock. Excessive vomiting can also cause metabolic abnormalities, most commonly hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis.

The acute management of a patient with suspected pyloric stenosis consists of assessing and addressing the ABCDE’s. If the patient is unstable, the airway, breathing, and circulation should be stabilized. Stabilizing circulation includes obtaining IV access and providing IV fluid resuscitation. It is also essential to correct electrolyte abnormalities in these patients. Once the patient is hemodynamically stable, abdominal ultrasound can be obtained to confirm the diagnosis of pyloric stenosis.Once electrolyte abnormalities and fluid status are corrected, the patient can proceed to the operating room for surgical pyloromyotomy.  

Option Analysis

✅ IV fluid resuscitation and IV electrolyte repletion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Oral rehydration with electrolyte-containing solution:
Incorrect: While oral rehydration is a reasonable starting point for certain patients with dehydration, this patient’s presentation is highly concerning for pyloric stenosis, and he should therefore be kept nil per os (NPO) until the diagnosis is confirmed. Furthermore, given that he has findings consistent with severe dehydration/hypovolemia, and he has electrolyte abnormalities. He should receive IV fluid resuscitation and IV electrolyte repletion.  
❌ Abdominal ultrasound:
Incorrect: While this patient’s presentation is highly concerning for pyloric stenosis, and abdominal ultrasound is the imaging modality of choice to confirm this diagnosis, he is currently hemodynamically unstable due to hypovolemia, and must first be stabilized with IV fluid resuscitation and electrolyte repletion.
❌ Fluoroscopic upper-gastrointestinal (GI) series:
Incorrect: While this patient’s presentation is highly concerning for pyloric stenosis, and imaging should be obtained to confirm the diagnosis, abdominal ultrasound, not upper GI series, is the initial imaging modality of choice. This hemodynamically unstable patient should be stabilized with IV fluid resuscitation and electrolyte repletion before imaging is obtained.  
❌ Urgent pyloromyotomy:
Incorrect: While this patient’s presentation is highly concerning for pyloric stenosis, for which pyloromyotomy is the definitive treatment, this diagnosis has not been confirmed with imaging, and the priority in the management of this hemodynamically unstable patient is IV fluid resuscitation and electrolyte repletion.

questions.text:
A 6-week-old girl presents to the emergency department (ED) with recurrent postprandial emesis. She was born at term via cesarean section, has no known medical conditions and is primarily formula-fed. Her parents report that she has had intermittent episodes of non-bilious postprandial emesis since birth, but over the last several days they have become more frequent and forceful, even “shooting across the room” per her parent. She was seen by her pediatrician two days ago and an alternative formula was recommended; however, her symptoms have persisted. Her last wet diaper was approximately 8 hours ago and her last bowel movement occurred yesterday and was normal in character. In the ED, her temperature is 36.2 °C (97.2 ºF), pulse is 165/min, blood pressure is 68/35 mmHg, and SpO2 is 99%. Results of laboratory studies are shown. Abdominal ultrasound shows a target sign. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Hypertrophy of the circular and longitudinal muscle fibers of the pylorus
Incomplete counterclockwise rotation of the midgut around the superior mesenteric pedicle

questions.solution:
In this 6-week-old girl with persistent postprandial emesis that is forceful, non-bilious, and not accompanied by other gastrointestinal or systemic symptoms, pyloric stenosis should be suspected. Laboratory studies demonstrating hypokalemia, hypochloremia, elevated bicarbonate, and indirect hyperbilirubinemia support the diagnosis of pyloric stenosis, and the finding of a thickened pylorus (target sign) confirms it. Pyloric stenosis is caused by hypertrophy of the circular and longitudinal muscle fibers of the pylorus.

The circular and longitudinal muscle fibers of the pylorus act as a muscular valve between the stomach and the duodenum. Hypertrophy of these muscles can result in pyloric stenosis. This most commonly presents between 2 and 6 weeks of age. Pyloric stenosis often leads to complete or near-complete gastric outlet obstruction, which can present as forceful postprandial vomiting that is non-bilious, as the stomach fills with ingested liquid that is unable to pass into the duodenum. Excessive vomiting in turn causes dehydration and metabolic abnormalities like hypokalemic and hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis. The diagnosis is confirmed by abdominal ultrasound. Ultrasound may show evidence of a thickened and elongated pylorus that can be seen as a “target sign”.
 

Transverse ultrasound of pyloric stenosis shows a cross-sectional view of the thickened pylorus (“target sign”). The diameter is measured between the 1 calipers, and the single wall thickness is measured between the 2 calipers.  

Option Analysis

✅ Hypertrophy of the circular and longitudinal muscle fibers of the pylorus:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Viral infection:
Incorrect: Viral infection can cause Gastroenteritis with emesis and dehydration in infants. However, it is typically accompanied by diarrhea, fever, and leukocytosis.  
❌ Incompetent lower esophageal sphincter:
Incorrect: Gastroesophageal reflux (GER) is a common cause of emesis in infants and is in part caused by the incompletely developed lower esophageal sphincter. However, emesis is typically intermittent and does not cause significant dehydration or electrolyte abnormalities.  
❌ Incomplete counterclockwise rotation of the midgut around the superior mesenteric pedicle:
Incorrect: Intestinal malrotation results from the partial or complete failure of the midgut to rotate 270 degrees around the superior mesenteric pedicle during fetal development. This can lead to volvulus, which can cause recurrent emesis and significant dehydration. However, emesis is typically bilious.  
❌ Type I hypersensitivity reaction:
Incorrect: Milk protein allergy can result from an IgE-mediated type I hypersensitivity reaction and cause emesis in infants. However, emesis is often accompanied by respiratory and/or cutaneous symptoms and does not cause significant dehydration or electrolyte abnormalities.

The prior emergency department physician reported that the patient was initially tachycardic and hypotensive, and his parents stated that he had not voided in at least 12 hours. IV access was obtained, IV fluid resuscitation was initiated, and his hemodynamics began to improve prior to transfer. After transfer to the pediatric hospital, an abdominal ultrasound was obtained and findings confirmed the diagnosis of pyloric stenosis. Today, his temperature is 36.8 °C (98.2 ºF), pulse is 140/min, blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg, and SpO2 is 100% on room air. Laboratory results from this morning are shown below. He has had 2 wet diapers in the last 12 hours, no bowel movements, and no further episodes of emesis. He remains nil per os (NPO) with weight-based maintenance IV fluids running. What is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Fluid resuscitation and repeat blood work
Resumption of oral feeding once the patient has flatus/bowel movement

questions.solution:
In this patient with a confirmed diagnosis of pyloric stenosis by abdominal ultrasound, the definitive treatment is surgical pyloromyotomy. However, the initial step in management is holding oral feeds, correcting hypovolemia through IV fluid resuscitation, and correcting metabolic abnormalities. While this patient is no longer tachycardic, hypotensive, oliguric, or hypokalemic, he has persistent hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis that must be corrected preoperatively. Therefore, the next step in management is to continue appropriate IV fluid resuscitation and repeat blood work later in the day, targeting Cl >/=100 and CO2 (bicarbonate) </= 30.

Patients with pyloric stenosis typically present with some degree of dehydration, ranging from mild dehydration to hypovolemic shock. This is often accompanied by metabolic abnormalities, most commonly hypokalemic, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to prolonged persistent vomiting. In these patients, surgical pyloromyotomy is needed, but it is safest and best for the patient to ensure adequate resuscitation and medical optimization before surgery. In addition to normalization of vital signs and urine output, surgeons and anesthesiologists want to see a resolution of hypokalemia, to prevent cardiac arrhythmias, and metabolic alkalosis, to prevent depressed respiratory drive leading to prolonged postoperative intubation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Fluid resuscitation and repeat blood work:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Immediate surgical pyloromyotomy:
Incorrect: While surgical pyloromyotomy is the definitive treatment for pyloric stenosis and should be performed in this patient, his blood work demonstrates a persistent hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis which should be corrected prior to surgery.  
❌ Trial of oral feeding:
Incorrect: While a trial of oral feeding would be appropriate for patients with certain conditions like gastroenteritis, this patient has a radiographically confirmed diagnosis of pyloric stenosis, and should not be given oral feeds until the problem is surgically corrected.  
❌ Nasogastric tube placement:
Incorrect: Nasogastric (NG) tubes can be placed for gastric decompression or for enteral feeding. In patients with pyloric stenosis, NG tubes are not typically required for gastric decompression preoperatively, and this patient has not vomited since oral feeds were stopped. Additionally, enteral feeds (either oral or via NG tube) should not be started until the existing gastric outlet obstruction is surgically corrected with pyloromyotomy.  
❌ Resumption of oral feeding once the patient has flatus/bowel movement:
Incorrect: This patient has a confirmed diagnosis of pyloric stenosis, meaning a complete or near-complete gastric outlet obstruction is present which will need to be surgically corrected. Passage of flatus may occur if the obstruction is incomplete, and bowel movements may occur even in the presence of a complete obstruction. However, neither of these indications of bowel function beyond the pylorus would suggest that the patient will tolerate oral feeding.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with acute onset chest pain for the past 30 minutes. The pain started suddenly during dinner. The patient describes the pain as crushing substernal pain and rates it as 8/10. She recalls a few occasions of similar pain episodes but did not seek treatment because she thought it would pass. Medical history is significant for smoking 1 pack per day for 30 years. The patient has not noticed any relation to specific foods and does not have any reflux symptoms. The patient took her partner’s sublingual nitroglycerin pill before the ambulance arrival, which provided partial relief. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. ECG is performed and shows normal sinus rhythm with no significant ST-changes. A barium swallow is performed and is shown below:  



Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the best initial treatment for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with a sudden onset of non-exertional chest pain. The ECG is negative for ischemic changes, and the barium swallow test shows a classic “corkscrew” pattern, favoring the diagnosis of diffuse esophageal spasm (DES).   

DES is a medical condition characterized by uncoordinated esophageal contractions that presents as dysphagia, regurgitation and chest pain. The pain often mimics myocardial ischemia, but a key differentiating factor is that DES is not exertional. There is minimal relationship to food, but it can be triggered by cold fluids. Barium study may show a “corkscrew”’ pattern at the time of the spasm. On manometry, high intensity, disorganized contractions are typically seen.    

Treatment depends on the severity of symptoms and the presence of associated gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). For patients with associated GERD, first-line treatment includes proton pump inhibitors (PPI), with H2 blockers as second-line; this strategy comes from the theory that esophageal spasm may be triggered by acid reflux. For those who experience dysphagia and/or noncardiac chest pain without GERD symptoms, first-line treatment includes peppermint oil; the second-line treatment is calcium channel blockers (i.e. diltiazem). If initial measures fail, other options may include nitroglycerin, antidepressants (e.g., imipramine, SSRI), and phosphodiesterase inhibitors (sildenafil). For refractory cases, botulinum toxin injections can assist in the treatment.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Proton pump inhibitors:
Incorrect:  Proton pump inhibitors are used to treat conditions such as peptic ulcers, gastritis, and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). It can be used in patients with diffuse esophageal spasms as first-line treatment if there is concomitant reflux. This is due to the hypothesis that esophageal spasm may be triggered by acid reflux. However, this patient reported no GERD symptoms.   
❌ Nitroglycerin :
Incorrect: Nitroglycerin may be used in patients with diffuse esophageal spasms without gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or with well-controlled GERD symptoms, but it is not the first line. Additionally, its usage may be limited due to side effects such as headaches.    
✅ Peppermint oil:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Imipramine:
Incorrect: Imipramine is a tricyclic antidepressant that can be used in patients with diffuse esophageal spasms without gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) or with well-controlled GERD symptoms, but it is not the first line. It can be considered after the first and second-line therapies have failed.   
❌ Ranitidine:
Incorrect: Ranitidine is an H2 blocker used to treat conditions such as peptic ulcer, gastritis, and gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). It can also be used in patients with diffuse esophageal spasms as second-line treatment if there is concomitant reflux (PPIs are first-line). This is due to the hypothesis that esophageal spasm may be induced by acid reflux. This patient reports no GERD symptoms.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old man is hospitalized for recurrent pneumonia. This is the patient’s fourth hospitalization for pneumonia in the past six months, and bronchial lavage cultures have consistently grown Bacteroides sp susceptible to ampicillin-sulbactam. The patient undergoes a barium swallow study as demonstrated below during his hospitalization. Which of the following correctly identifies the anatomic location of this patient’s clinical condition?  


Reproduced from: Wikipedia

choices.text: Junction between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus
Junction between the middle and inferior pharyngeal constrictors muscles
Junction between the upper part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictors
Junction between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors
Junction between the circular and longitudinal fibers of the esophagus

questions.solution:
This patient presents with recurrent aspiration pneumonia, as evidenced by culture data growing oral flora. This patient's barium swallow study demonstrates an outpouching of the cervical esophagus, most consistent with a Zenker diverticulum.  

Zenker diverticulum refers to an outpouching of the esophageal mucosa and submucosa through Killian’s triangle (also called Killian’s dehiscence), an area in the posterior wall of the pharynx between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus (the two parts of the inferior constrictors). The pathogenesis of Zenker’s diverticulum is thought to be due to altered function of the upper esophageal sphincter (cricopharyngeus), esophageal dysmotility, and esophageal shortening. Dysfunction of these muscle groups results in impaired bolus passage, increased intraluminal pressure, and subsequent protrusion of mucosa and submucosa through Killian's triangle.  

Clinical features include recurrent dysphagia, halitosis, and cough. A common complication of this condition is recurrent aspiration pneumonia. If small, a Zenker diverticulum is treated conservatively; larger diverticula are traditionally treated with surgery to incise the cricopharyngeus muscle and resect the diverticulum.  

Option Analysis

✅ Junction between the cricopharyngeus and thyropharyngeus:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Junction between the middle and inferior pharyngeal constrictors muscles:
Incorrect: The area between the middle and inferior pharyngeal constrictors muscles is not involved in a Zenker diverticulum's pathogenesis.
❌ Junction between the upper part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictors  :
Incorrect: The thyropharyngeus muscle refers to the upper part of the inferior pharyngeal constrictors muscle, which is not the site of formation of a Zenker diverticulum.
❌ Junction between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors:
Incorrect: The junction between the superior and middle pharyngeal constrictors is not involved in the pathogenesis of a Zenker diverticulum. 
❌ Junction between the circular and longitudinal fibers of the esophagus:
Incorrect: The junction between the circular and longitudinal fibers of the esophagus is not involved in Zenker diverticulum formation.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman presents to the primary care physician with a chief complaint of post-prandial abdominal pain and dyspepsia. The patient reports the symptoms started approximately 3-4 weeks ago and have been worsening in intensity. The patient’s only other medical problem is osteoarthritis, for which she occasionally receives corticosteroid injections and recently started taking diclofenac daily. Current temperature is  37 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 86/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 142/62 mmHg. Physical examination shows epigastric tenderness on palpation. Which of the following is the best initial management for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of recent initiation of diclofenac and epigastric pain raises concern for peptic ulcer disease or gastritis due to NSAIDs. The first step in management is discontinuation of the offending agent, which in this case is diclofenac. The risk of peptic ulcer disease is magnified in patients also taking glucocorticoids, those with a history of peptic ulcer disease, and patients over age 60. Additional therapeutic interventions include the use of proton pump inhibitors, H-2 blockers, and evaluation for concurrent H. pylori infection.  

NSAIDs, including naproxen, aspirin, ketorolac, and diclofenac, inhibit cyclooxygenase, with all of them being reversible agents aside from aspirin. Cyclooxygenase, or COX, mediates production of prostaglandins, which help to maintain the barrier function of gastric mucosa by enhancing bicarbonate secretion, mucous production, epithelial hyperplasia, as well as mucosal blood flow via vasodilation. Specifically, this process is mediated by PGE2. Most of these gastric interactions are mediated by COX-1, as opposed to COX-2 which is expressed constitutively throughout the body. As the barrier function breaks down due to NSAID-induced COX inhibition, gastric acid erodes the mucosa, eventually leading to gastritis or ulcer formation. If left untreated, gastric ulcers can cause significant gastrointestinal bleeding, anemia, or perforation.  

Option Analysis

✅ Discontinuation of diclofenac:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administration of omeprazole:
Incorrect: Proton pump inhibitor therapy should be considered in patients with gastritis or peptic ulcer disease in the setting of NSAID use to decrease gastric pH and promote healing. However, the most important initial intervention is to discontinue the offending agent, which in this case is diclofenac.   
❌ Administration of sucralfate:
Incorrect: Sucralfate can be used for symptomatic relief of peptic ulcer disease. It works by stimulating angiogenesis and the formation of granulation tissue, possibly via growth factor binding. However, the most important initial intervention is to discontinue the offending agent, which in this case is diclofenac.   
❌ Administration of viscous lidocaine:
Incorrect: Viscous lidocaine can help provide symptomatic relief to patients with acute exacerbations of peptic ulcer disease, GERD, and gastritis, but it does provide long-term symptomatic relief, nor will it treat the underlying cause of this patient’s symptoms.   
❌ Urgent upper endoscopy and ligation :
Incorrect: Upper endoscopy should be considered for this patient’s symptoms after the discontinuation of diclofenac. However, this patient does not have alarm features of hemodynamic instability, weight loss, or vomiting, making urgent endoscopy with ligation or clipping of a peptic ulcer unnecessary.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the primary care physician with a several week history of worsening epigastric pain, dyspepsia, and intermittent vomiting. The patient reports taking omeprazole at home without relief of the symptoms. Past medical history includes coronary artery disease and hypertension, for which he takes aspirin and hydrochlorothiazide. Temperature is 37°C (98.6 °F), pulse is 72/min, respirations are 16/min and blood pressure is 132/62 mmHg. Physical exam shows mild tenderness on palpation of the epigastrium. The patient is instructed to discontinue the omeprazole for one week. After 1 week, an upper endoscopy is performed, revealing a single non-bleeding duodenal ulcer. Which of the following best describes the test of choice to establish the underlying etiology of this patient’s ulcer?
questions.solution:
H. pylori is the culprit in >90% of duodenal ulcers and nearly 70% of gastric ulcers. Due to this high rate of incidence, all patients with peptic ulcer disease should undergo evaluation for H. pylori infection, as treatment with triple therapy has demonstrated high rates of eradication. Usually, this treatment consists of amoxicillin, clarithromycin, and a proton pump inhibitor.   

Diagnosis of H. pylori infection is dependent on the clinical features and risk factors of the patient in question. For patients without alarm features that would require endoscopy, a urease breath test or stool antigen assay is appropriate initial testing. For patients with alarm features (vomiting, weight loss, palpable mass, dysphagia, unexplained anemia), endoscopy should be performed. Patients with a recent history of proton pump inhibitor use, bismuth or antibiotic use may yield false negative results with a biopsy urease test. In these patients, biopsy with histology will provide definitive diagnosis for the organism.   

Option Analysis

✅ Biopsy with histology:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hydrolysis of urea to ammonia:
Incorrect: The rapid urease test may either be performed as a biopsy or as a breath test. The test relies on the bacteria’s use of urease to facilitate the hydrolysis of urea by H. pylori to produce CO2 and ammonia. In patients without alarm features that would require endoscopy, the urease breath test is a reasonable approach. However, this patient has vomiting and should undergo endoscopy for evaluation. The recent use of omeprazole produces higher false negative results for the urease test, requiring biopsy with histology for definitive diagnosis.  
❌ Immunoassay of a bacterial antigen:
Incorrect: The stool antigen assay can be used in the establishment of both initial infection and eradication of infection with H. pylori. This assay is not performed in patients undergoing endoscopy for establishment of diagnosis.  
❌ Measurement of serum gastrin levels:
Incorrect: Measurement of serum gastrin levels is performed in patients with concern for Zollinger-Ellison syndrome, or a gastrinoma. These patients typically present with multiple ulcers, unlike this patient.  
❌ Measurement of CA19-9:
Incorrect:  CA19-9 is a tumor marker for pancreatic cancer, which more commonly presents with painless jaundice and weight loss, which this patient does not have.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation of vomiting up blood three times since yesterday. The patient states that each time he vomited a cup full of vomitus with bright red blood in it. The patient has three alcoholic drinks per day, and his last alcoholic drink was yesterday. Past medical history is significant for alcohol use disorder and major depressive disorder. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102/min, respirations are 18/min, blood pressure is 85/55 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 97% on room air. Physical examination shows jaundiced skin and icteric sclerae. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Obtain doppler ultrasound of the abdomen
Intubate the patient for emergent upper endoscopy
Transfuse 1 unit of packed red blood cells

questions.solution:
Gastroesophageal varices are abnormally enlarged veins in the distal esophagus and stomach. They arise when the veins that connect the portal circulation with the systemic circulation become dilated due to portal hypertension. Bleeding gastroesophageal varices typically occur in the distal esophagus or proximal stomach in individuals with advanced liver disease. Bleeding risk of varices is proportional to varix size.

When assessing a patient with signs and symptoms of suspected gastroesophageal variceal bleed, the first step is to perform an ABCDE assessment to determine whether the patient is stable or unstable. If the patient is unstable, acute management includes assessing and stabilizing the airway, breathing, and circulation. This includes providing supplemental oxygen or sometimes intubating the patient to protect the airway, establishing IV access with two 16-gauge peripheral intravenous catheters, and possibly performing gastric lavage to remove bloody stomach contents. Additionally, fluid resuscitation should be given to prevent death from hemorrhagic shock; if the patient does not stabilize with IV fluids, they may need a non-crossmatched blood transfusion.  

Option Analysis

❌ Obtain doppler ultrasound of the abdomen:
Incorrect: Doppler ultrasound is indicated for the evaluation of suspected portal vein thrombosis or compression. While this patient might have an underlying portal vein thrombosis, establishing intravenous access should be first-line treatment at this time given the patient’s hemodynamic instability.  
❌ Intubate the patient for emergent upper endoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient is hypotensive but is awake, alert, and able to protect his airway at this time. Intubation for emergent endoscopy should be pursued in patients with active upper gastrointestinal bleeding and those who are obtunded and hemodynamically unstable.  
✅ Place two 16-gauge peripheral intravenous catheters:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Administer broad spectrum antibiotics:
Incorrect: Broad-spectrum antibiotics are indicated in the treatment of esophageal varices to prevent bacterial infection. To confirm the diagnosis of varices, an endoscopy should be performed after hemodynamic stabilization of the patient and obtaining a focused history and physical.  
❌ Transfuse 1 unit of packed red blood cells:
Incorrect: Patients with bleeding esophageal varices may require blood transfusions if they are unresponsive to intravenous fluids. To administer fluids, the best next step is to establish intravenous access. If the patient does not stabilize with IV fluids, they may need a non-crossmatched blood transfusion.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents to the primary care clinic due to three days of severe abdominal pain, bloating, and increased belching. The pain has a burning sensation and is located in the upper abdomen. It is the worst in the morning and after meals. No family members have similar symptoms. Past medical history is significant for recurrent migraines, for which the patient takes high-dose naproxen several times per week. Vital signs are unremarkable. On physical examination, there is moderate tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium. Stool antigen testing is negative for Helicobacter pylori infection. Which of the following medications should be given at this time?

choices.text: Calcium carbonate and tramadol for migraines

questions.solution:
Treatment of peptic ulcer disease (PUD) is accomplished with anti-secretory therapy, which is generally a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) such as omeprazole or pantoprazole. In cases where a PPI cannot be used, H2-receptor-antagonists (e.g. famotidine) can be used as alternatives. In cases of bleeding, PPIs also help create a favorable environment for platelet adherence and function. If possible, patients taking NSAIDs or corticosteroids should discontinue these medications. Patients should also be counseled on alcohol and tobacco cessation. In most cases, anti-secretory therapy should be continued for at least 4-8 weeks and then can be stopped. NSAIDs should be discontinued if possible.

All patients with suspected PUD should be tested for Helicobacter pylori infection with either stool antigen or urea breath testing. If they are getting an EGD, then testing can be done through endoscopy with biopsies. Treatment of Helicobacter pylori infection generally consists of a combination of 3 or 4 medications that include antibiotics, an antisecretory medication, and/or bismuth subsalicylate. A common treatment regimen consists of amoxicillin, clarithromycin, and a PPI. After treatment, eradication should be confirmed via a stool antigen test, urea breath test, or endoscopy with biopsy. If the infection persists, the patient should receive another course of antibiotics.

For patients with recurrent ulcers or patients over 50 years old who have giant ulcers (>2 cm), long-term antisecretory therapy should be initiated. Moreover, patients who require chronic NSAID use should also receive long-term antisecretory therapy.  

Option Analysis

✅ Omeprazole:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Calcium carbonate:
Incorrect: Calcium carbonate can be used to reduce symptoms of esophageal reflux and peptic ulcer disease, but first-line treatment of PUD is anti-secretory treatment with a PPI, or in certain cases an H2-receptor-antagonist.  
❌ Calcium carbonate and tramadol for migraines:
Incorrect: Calcium carbonate can be used to reduce symptoms of esophageal reflux and peptic ulcer disease, but first-line treatment of suspected PUD is anti-secretory treatment with a PPI, or in certain cases an H2-receptor-antagonist. Tramadol can be considered for pain control instead of NSAIDs, but this patient still would need anti-secretory medication for NSAID-induced PUD.  
❌ Amoxicillin, clarithromycin, and pantoprazole:
Incorrect: If this patient had a confirmed Helicobacter pylori infection, then this drug combination would be the best treatment option. However, this patient is more likely to have NSAID-induced peptic ulcer disease since Helicobacter pylori testing is negative.  
❌ Famotidine and meloxicam for migraines:
Incorrect: H2-receptor-antagonists (e.g. famotidine, ranitidine) can be used as anti-secretory therapy in place of proton pump inhibitors (PPI) in certain cases. However, while meloxicam causes less gastric irritation than naproxen (due to COX-2 selectivity), all NSAIDs should be avoided if possible in patients with active peptic ulcer disease.

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman with a history of peptic ulcer disease and atrial fibrillation on warfarin is hospitalized with septic shock from a urinary tract infection. She is given IV fluids, antibiotics, and norepinephrine. She clinically improves and is weaned off the vasopressor. On hospital day 4, she has several episodes of coffee ground emesis. Temperature is 37 °C (98.6 °F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 16/min, blood pressure is 110/78 mmHg, and oxygen saturation is 100% on room air. Upper endoscopy shows deep erosions in the antrum of the stomach, one of which has a visible vessel. Which of the following is the best next step in management?

choices.text: Order pantoprazole and interventional radiology consultation
Order sucralfate and interventional radiology consultation

questions.solution:
This patient with risk factors for the development of stress ulcers and episodes of coffee ground emesis was found to have multiple gastric ulcers on endoscopy and a visible vessel.

Stress ulcers are erosions of the upper GI mucosa that result from stressors, such as shock, trauma, hypovolemia, and excessive stimulation of parietal cells by gastrin. Bleeding from these erosions can result in the clinical manifestations of anemia, hematemesis, melena, tachycardia, and hypotension.

In cases of significant bleeding from a presumed stress ulcer, pantoprazole and upper endoscopy are indicated. This procedure not only allows for visualization and identification of the ulcer and its severity, but it can be used for therapeutic interventions, such as clip placement, thermal coagulation, and injection of epinephrine when indicated. Shallow, superficial stress ulcers can be managed with proton pump inhibitors (PPI) alone. Deep-stress ulcers may be more complex, particularly if there is active bleeding or a visible vessel within the ulcerated mucosa. In these circumstances, consultation with interventional radiology (for potential embolization) or surgery is indicated in addition to PPI therapy.

Option Analysis

❌ Order pantoprazole:
Incorrect: A proton pump inhibitor, such as pantoprazole, would be indicated to suppress gastric acid production. However, deep stress ulcers with a visible vessel are at high risk for rebleeding. Thus, a surgical or interventional radiology consultation would also be warranted.  
❌ Order famotidine:
