Incorrect: Esophageal candidiasis typically occurs in patients with underlying immunosuppression (e.g. HIV). Patients will typically have evidence of oral thrush. 
❌ Discontinue amlodipine:
Incorrect: Pill esophagitis typically presents in patients who take agents known to cause pill esophagitis, especially if taken with little or no water before bed. These include bisphosphonates, tetracycline antibiotics, and NSAIDs. Amlodipine does not typically cause pill esophagitis.
❌ Administer prednisone:
Incorrect: Corticosteroids are the mainstay of treatment for eosinophilic esophagitis. This specific subtype of esophagitis is found in patients with atopic conditions (e.g. asthma) and occurs due to chronic inflammation of the esophagus caused by antigen sensitization.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man presents to the clinic with one month of nausea, vomiting, and early satiety. Past medical history is significant for congestive heart failure, type II diabetes mellitus, schizophrenia, and a prior episode of tardive dyskinesia. Current medications include aripiprazole, carvedilol, lisinopril, metformin, and pioglitazone. On physical examination there are hypoactive bowel sounds and an abdominal succussion splash is present. There is no significant tenderness to abdominal palpation. Laboratory values include a prolactin of 120 ng/mL and hemoglobin A1c of 12%. Which of the following medications is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Domperidone is an anti-dopaminergic agent used for treating gastroparesis. These days, it has largely been replaced by metoclopramide. Domperidone can help symptoms related to gastroparesis by inhibiting dopaminergic pathways in the brain and promoting muscarinic receptor-mediated gastric emptying.      

Domperidone increases the risk for tardive dyskinesia, which is a movement disorder thought to arise from an imbalance of dopamine blockade and overactivation of D1 receptors. Concomitant use of antipsychotics (e.g., haloperidol, aripiprazole) is a relative contraindication to domperidone therapy. A prior history of tardive dyskinesia is an absolute contraindication.      

Additional relative contraindications include hyperprolactinemia and prolonged QT intervals whereas mechanical bowel obstruction is another absolute contraindication.  

Option Analysis

❌ Erythromycin:
Incorrect: This patient presents with symptoms suggestive of gastroparesis. Erythromycin has promotility properties that can be used to manage the symptoms of gastroparesis. There are no contraindications to the use of erythromycin in this patient. 
❌ Diphenhydramine:
Incorrect: Diphenhydramine reduces nausea by antagonizing H1-receptors in the vestibular apparatus and is not helpful in managing the symptoms of gastroparesis. While they are not contraindicated in this patient, first-generation antihistamines should be used sparingly as they have many side effects.
❌ Empagliflozin:
Incorrect: This patient has no contraindication to SGLT-2 inhibitors and would probably benefit from one given his history of congestive heart failure and hypertension. Contraindications include frequent urinary tract infections as well as a history of euglycemic diabetic ketoacidosis or Fournier gangrene.
❌ Granisetron:
Incorrect: Granisetron, like ondansetron, is a 5-HT3 antagonist that works in the chemoreceptor trigger zone. While it does not help gastroparesis-related nausea very much, it is not contraindicated in this patient.
✅ Domperidone:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 50-year-old man comes to the office because of pain from swallowing and retrosternal burning chest pain for the past two weeks. The patient’s symptoms have progressively worsened over time. Past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus and chronic kidney disease. The patient underwent an uncomplicated renal transplantation 6-months ago. He takes metformin, semaglutide, mycophenolate mofetil, and cyclosporine. Temperature is 38.8°C (102°F), pulse is 100/min, respirations are 15/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. Physical examination shows marked epigastric tenderness. The oral mucosa is moist without any ulcerations. Cardiopulmonary examination is within normal limits. Leukocyte count is 6,000/mm3. Esophagogastroduodenoscopy shows linear, shallow ulcers in the lower esophagus. Biopsy revealed intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient’s presentation with progressive retrosternal chest pain and pain with swallowing, in combination with endoscopy findings of linear, shallow ulcers in the lower esophagus with intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions, is suggestive of cytomegalovirus (CMV) esophagitis, most likely due to immunosuppression following renal transplantation. The treatment of choice is intravenous ganciclovir.   

Ganciclovir, a guanosine analog, is triphosphorylated to form a nucleotide that inhibits DNA polymerases of CMV and herpes simplex virus (HSV) to cause chain termination. Ganciclovir is initially phosphorylated by the enzyme UL-97 kinase, which is found in CMV and HSV-infected cells. It is mainly used for prophylaxis and treatment of CMV retinitis and other CMV infections in immunocompromised patients (e.g., esophagitis, as in this patient). CMV resistance mechanisms involve mutations in the genes that code for the activating viral phosphotransferase and the viral DNA polymerase. Thymidine kinase-deficient HSV strains are also resistant to ganciclovir.  

It causes serious side effects, including suppression of the bone marrow, which manifests as leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, and anemia. Other side effects include nephrotoxicity, hepatotoxicity, mucositis, and seizures.  

Option Analysis

❌ Acyclovir:
Incorrect: Acyclovir is an effective treatment option for HSV esophagitis, which presents with well-circumscribed lesions with a round-oval “volcano-like appearance”. This patient’s shallow linear ulcers with intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions are suggestive of CMV infection. Acyclovir is not indicated for CMV infections.
❌ Fluconazole:
Incorrect: Fluconazole is the treatment of choice in candida esophagitis, which typically presents with a white plaque on endoscopy. Shallow linear ulcers with intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusions are not seen.
✅ Ganciclovir:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Omeprazole :
Incorrect: Omeprazole is an effective treatment option for gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). It usually presents with heartburn and reflux of acidic material in the mouth. The presence of shallow linear ulcers in the lower esophagus is suggestive of CMV infection.
❌ Symptomatic therapy:
Incorrect: Symptomatic therapy would be appropriate in patients with aphthous ulcers. This patient most likely has cytomegalovirus esophagitis and should receive treatment with ganciclovir.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl presents with a 3-month history of intermittent epigastric pain that worsens at night and is partially relieved by eating. There is no history of vomiting or weight loss, and the patient has not been taking nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). The patient was started on omeprazole but has had no improvement in symptoms despite four weeks of treatment. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate is 94/min, blood pressure is 110/70 mmHg, respiratory rate is 20/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The patient appears comfortable on the examination table. Abdominal palpation reveals mild tenderness in the epigastric region without guarding or rebound. Laboratory testing is notable for a hemoglobin of 10 g/dL and mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 75 fL. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) reveals mucosal erythema and multiple erosions in the stomach, and rapid urease testing is positive. What is the best next step in management?

choices.text: No change in pharmacotherapy with repeat EGD in 4 weeks
Antibiotic therapy and urea breath test in 4 weeks
H2 receptor antagonist therapy and repeat EGD in 2 weeks
Stool antigen testing for confirmation before starting treatment

questions.solution:
This patient presents with ongoing epigastric pain despite a trial of proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy. EGD findings are consistent with gastritis, and a positive rapid urease test confirms Helicobacter pylori infection. The next step is to add two antibiotics to the current PPI regimen (i.e. triple therapy), and confirmation of eradication should be performed at least 4 weeks after completing the treatment course.

The treatment of pediatric peptic ulcers, gastritis, or duodenitis begins with identifying and discontinuing offending agents, such as NSAIDs, that impair gastric mucosal defenses. Acid suppression with a PPI (e.g. omeprazole) is the cornerstone of therapy, as it promotes mucosal healing and provides symptom relief. If H. pylori infection is confirmed, triple therapy consisting of a PPI and two antibiotics (e.g., amoxicillin, clarithromycin, or metronidazole) is initiated. Eradication should be confirmed after 4 weeks, typically using noninvasive tests such as a urea breath test or stool antigen test.

Option Analysis

❌ No change in pharmacotherapy with repeat EGD in 4 weeks:
Incorrect: Repeat EGD is unnecessary, as the diagnosis of Helicobacter pylori has already been confirmed with EGD and rapid urease testing. The appropriate next step is to initiate triple therapy and test for eradication in 4 weeks.
✅ Antibiotic therapy and urea breath test in 4 weeks:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ H2 receptor antagonist therapy and repeat EGD in 2 weeks:
Incorrect: This patient has already failed proton pump inhibitor (PPI) monotherapy, and an H2 receptor antagonist alone will not address the underlying Helicobacter pylori infection. The appropriate next step is to initiate triple therapy and test for eradication in 4 weeks.
❌ Antacids and follow-up in 4 weeks:
Incorrect: Antacids alone only provide symptomatic relief and do not treat Helicobacter pylori infection. The appropriate next step is to initiate triple therapy and test for eradication in 4 weeks.
❌ Stool antigen testing for confirmation before starting treatment:
Incorrect: The EGD and rapid urease testing have already confirmed Helicobacter pylori infection; further testing before initiating treatment is unnecessary. The appropriate next step is to initiate triple therapy and test for eradication in 4 weeks.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to clinic due to difficulty swallowing and recurrent vomiting over the past six months. The vomiting is non-bilious and occurs after meals, especially when eating solid foods such as bread and chicken. The child has started eating very slowly and will avoid meals altogether. There is no fever, abdominal pain, or diarrhea, but the child has lost 1.5 kg (3.3 lbs.) since his last visit eight months ago. Past medical history is significant for asthma and seasonal allergies. Vital signs are within normal limits. The child appears in no acute distress. Abdominal examination is unremarkable. Which of the following is the best next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Serum IgE and food allergy testing

questions.solution:
This 10-year-old child presents with symptoms suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE), including dysphagia, postprandial non-bilious vomiting, and a history of atopy (e.g., asthma and seasonal allergies). EoE is an immune-mediated condition that requires esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) with biopsy for diagnosis. Characteristic esophageal findings include rings, strictures, or linear furrows, along with histologic eosinophilic infiltration.       

The diagnostic workup for a pediatric patient with vomiting begins with a focused history and physical examination. Acute vomiting with bilious emesis may indicate intestinal obstruction from conditions such as superior mesenteric artery syndrome or pancreatitis. Imaging (e.g., upper GI series, CT, ultrasound) and laboratory studies (e.g., amylase, lipase) can help differentiate these conditions. The presence of diarrhea may point to infectious gastroenteritis, and stool studies can identify the pathogen. In the absence of diarrhea or bilious vomiting, infections like UTI or pharyngitis may be considered and evaluated with urine studies or rapid strep testing, respectively.        

Chronic vomiting requires evaluation for conditions such as EoE, celiac disease, or gastroparesis, often utilizing EGD with biopsy, total IgA and anti-TTG IgA levels, or motility studies. Episodic vomiting, particularly early morning vomiting, suggests cyclic vomiting syndrome or increased intracranial pressure and warrants an assessment using Rome IV criteria or neuroimaging, respectively. In contrast, vomiting related to food or fluid intake may indicate an eating disorder or uteropelvic junction (UPJ) obstruction, which should be confirmed with a validated screening tool or renal ultrasound, respectively.   

Option Analysis

❌ Serum IgE and food allergy testing:
Incorrect: While serum IgE and food allergy testing can identify potential triggers and guide subsequent management for eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE), they do not diagnose the condition. These tests should be performed only after confirmation of the condition via endoscopy. 
✅ Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD):
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Upper gastrointestinal (UGI) series:
Incorrect: A UGI series can identify structural abnormalities (e.g., strictures or malrotation). However, this test lacks the sensitivity to diagnose eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE). EoE is primarily a histologic diagnosis, and EGD with biopsy is the preferred diagnostic tool. 
❌ Referral to a dietician:
Incorrect: Dietary management is a treatment option for eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE), particularly with elimination diets (i.e. empiric or targeted food elimination). However, dietary changes should follow diagnostic confirmation via EGD with biopsy. Implementing dietary changes without a confirmed diagnosis may delay appropriate treatment. 
❌ Computed tomography (CT) of the head:
Incorrect: CT imaging is not indicated in a patient with vomiting and dysphagia suggestive of eosinophilic esophagitis (EoE). Head imaging is more relevant in cases where neurologic symptoms or signs of increased intracranial pressure are present in association with vomiting.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old girl presents with a 3-month history of intermittent epigastric pain that worsens between meals and at night. The pain is partially relieved by eating and occasionally accompanied by nausea. The patient reports no vomiting or diarrhea but recently noticed dark, tarry stools. The family emigrated from Vietnam two years ago, and the father has a history of peptic ulcer disease (PUD). Vitals are within normal limits. On examination, the child appears pale, with mild tenderness in the epigastric region without guarding or rebound. Laboratory results are shown below. An esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) reveals an ulcer in the gastric antrum, and biopsies are taken. Which of the following is most likely to be seen on histology after biopsy of the gastric mucosa?

 Laboratory Test     Result    
 Hemoglobin     9.5 g/dL    
 Hematocrit     28%    
 Stool guaiac test     Positive

choices.text: Fungal hyphae with surrounding neutrophilic infiltration
Non-caseating granulomas with multinucleated giant cells

questions.solution:
This patient’s chronic epigastric pain, melena, anemia, positive stool guaiac test, and EGD finding of a gastric antral ulcer are consistent with peptic ulcer disease (PUD). The history of emigration from an endemic country and a family history of PUD are significant risk factors for Helicobacter pylori infection, a common cause of PUD in children. Histological examination of gastric biopsy specimens may reveal curved, gram-negative rods located in the mucosal layer overlying the gastric epithelium.

A diagnostic workup for a pediatric patient with suspected PUD, gastritis, or duodenitis may not be required, but those with alarm features should undergo testing. Laboratory evaluation may include a complete blood count to identify microcytic anemia and stool guaiac testing for occult blood.

Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) with biopsy is the gold standard to confirm the diagnosis. Mucosal erythema, erosions, and subepithelial hemorrhage in the stomach or duodenum are characteristic of gastritis or duodenitis, respectively. Mucosal ulceration is indicative of PUD. Histology may show inflammatory cells in gastritis and duodenitis or identify damage extending into the muscularis mucosa in the case of ulcers.

Histopathology may also reveal H. pylori organisms in some cases, but tissue culture is considered the gold standard for diagnosis. Other options include rapid urease testing, polymerase chain reaction, or fluorescent in situ hybridization.

Option Analysis

❌ Fungal hyphae with surrounding neutrophilic infiltration:
Incorrect: Fungal hyphae with surrounding neutrophilic infiltration are typically seen with fungal infections, such as Candida esophagitis, which is not associated with PUD. Esophageal candidiasis is commonly found in immunocompromised patients. This patient’s constellation of symptoms, diagnostic findings, and risk factors for Helicobacter pylori are consistent with PUD. Curved, gram-negative rods in the gastric mucosa are the most likely finding
✅ Curved, gram-negative rods:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Non-caseating granulomas with multinucleated giant cells:
Incorrect: Non-caseating granulomas with multinucleated giant cells are seen in granulomatous diseases like Crohn disease or sarcoidosis, which often present with chronic abdominal pain and diarrhea or systemic symptoms. This patient’s constellation of symptoms, diagnostic findings, and risk factors for Helicobacter pylori are consistent with PUD. Curved, gram-negative rods in the gastric mucosa are the most likely finding.
❌ Intranuclear inclusions with surrounding inflammation:
Incorrect: Intranuclear inclusions with surrounding inflammation are characteristic of viral infections, such as cytomegalovirus (CMV) or herpes simplex virus (HSV), especially in immunocompromised individuals. This patient’s constellation of symptoms, diagnostic findings, and risk factors for Helicobacter pylori are consistent with PUD. Curved, gram-negative rods in the gastric mucosa are the most likely finding.
❌ Basophilic stippling:
Incorrect: Basophilic stippling is not associated with PUD or Helicobacter pylori. It is more commonly seen in certain toxin exposures or metabolic conditions, such as lead poisoning. Instead, curved, gram-negative rods in the gastric mucosa are the most likely finding in this case.

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy is brought to the clinic due to frequent regurgitation after feedings. The caregiver reports frequent crying during and after feeding, occasional back arching, and reduced feeding volumes over the past two weeks. The infant has recently refused bottle-feeding and has had intermittent non-bloody, nonbilious vomiting. An upper respiratory tract infection occurred three weeks ago. There has not been fever, lethargy, bilious vomiting, hematemesis, or diarrhea. Weight is at the 25<sup>th</sup> percentile for age, down from the 45<sup>th</sup> percentile two months prior. Vital signs are within normal limits. On examination, the infant appears alert and active with no abnormal findings. Which of the following findings from the history and physical examination should prompt further evaluation?

choices.text: Crying and back arching during feedings

questions.solution:
This infant presents with frequent regurgitation, crying, back arching, and occasional vomiting, which are suggestive of gastroesophageal reflux disease. However, the decline in growth percentile indicating poor weight gain is an alarm sign that requires further evaluation.  

Gastroesophageal reflux (GER) is the backward flow of stomach contents into the esophagus. When this causes significant symptoms or complications such as esophagitis or Barrett esophagus, it is termed gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). In infants, GERD commonly presents with regurgitation, feeding refusal, irritability, and back arching during feeds. In older children and adolescents, symptoms may include heartburn, epigastric pain, nausea, or vomiting, along with anorexia or specific food aversions.

Clinicians should evaluate for warning signs that may suggest a diagnosis other than GERD. In infants, concerning features include onset of symptoms before 1 week or after 6 months of age, poor weight gain, fever, or lethargy. Neurologic signs such as seizures, abnormal head size, or a bulging fontanelle may indicate intracranial pathology. Other red flags include abdominal distention, hepatosplenomegaly, bilious or bloody vomiting, chronic diarrhea, and rectal bleeding. If any of these findings are present, further workup is warranted to assess for conditions such as intestinal obstruction, infection, or intracranial mass.

Option Analysis

❌ Crying and back arching during feedings:
Incorrect: These are common symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux in infants and do not warrant further workup in the absence of warning signs.
✅ Change in growth percentile:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent upper respiratory tract infection:
Incorrect: A resolved upper respiratory infection is unlikely to be related to the current feeding issues and does not require further evaluation.
❌ Bottle refusal for two weeks:
Incorrect: Temporary feeding aversion is a common symptom of gastroesophageal reflux   and should be managed with conservative measures unless accompanied by warning signs, such as suboptimal weight gain.
❌ Non-bloody, nonbilious vomiting:
Incorrect: Non-bloody, nonbilious vomiting is a hallmark of gastroesophageal reflux in infants and is not concerning without warning signs. Bloody or bilious vomiting are alarm features that should prompt further evaluation.

questions.text: A 6-month-old boy is brought to clinic due to frequent regurgitation and irritability during and after feedings for one month. The infant arches his back during feedings, cries excessively, and often refuses to finish formula bottles. Feeding occurs every 4 hours, with approximately 4 ounces consumed per feed. There is no bilious or bloody vomiting. The parents report no fever, diarrhea, lethargy, or respiratory symptoms. Weight is at the 45<sup>th</sup> percentile for age, and growth parameters are consistent with previous visits. Vital signs are within normal limits. The infant appears alert and well-hydrated. The abdomen is soft and non-tender, with no hepatosplenomegaly or palpable masses. Which of the following is the most appropriate initial step in management?

choices.text: Elimination of cow’s milk protein from the diet

questions.solution:
This infant’s symptoms of frequent regurgitation, irritability, and back arching during feeding are consistent with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). In the absence of alarm signs such as poor weight gain, bilious vomiting, hematemesis, or systemic symptoms, GERD is typically managed conservatively with thickened feedings using rice cereal or a commercial thickener, along with smaller, more frequent feedings. Counseling on avoiding tobacco exposure is also recommended.

If symptoms persist, elimination of cow’s milk protein from the diet can be considered. Formula-fed infants may transition to extensively hydrolyzed or amino acid-based formulas. For breast-fed infants, the breastfeeding parent can remove cow’s milk from their diet. If symptoms improve, this approach should be continued.

If symptoms continue despite these measures, referral to a pediatric gastroenterologist is appropriate for further evaluation. A proton pump inhibitor (PPI) may be considered if specialist evaluation is delayed, but only for severe symptoms and for a limited duration of 4 to 8 weeks.

Option Analysis

❌ Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy:
Incorrect: PPIs are not first-line treatment in infants with uncomplicated reflux due to limited benefit and potential risks. They may be considered if there are persistent, severe symptoms or evidence of acid-related complications.
✅ Thickened and smaller, frequent feedings:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Elimination of cow’s milk protein from the diet:
Incorrect: This is a second-line measure in the management of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), considered if conservative strategies fail or if there are signs of cow’s milk protein allergy (e.g., blood in stool, eczema, family history of atopy).
❌ Pediatric gastroenterologist referral:
Incorrect: Referral is not indicated unless symptoms are severe, refractory, or associated with alarm features such as failure to thrive, hematemesis, or bilious vomiting.
❌ Esophageal pH monitoring:
Incorrect: This test is reserved for infants with atypical symptoms or those not responding to diet modifications.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl gave presents to the pediatrician for abdominal pain. The patient reports bloating, increased burping, and burning epigastric pain. The symptoms worsen when the patient is hungry and improves after eating. The patient denies blood or mucus in the stools, mouth sores, rashes, or joint pain. She has experienced a 5 lb. weight loss over the last few months, that is unintentional. The patient does not have systemic symptoms. There is no significant family history of gastrointestinal disorders. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, blood pressure is 111/66 mm Hg, respirations are 14/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. On physical examination, the patient appears well. Cardiopulmonary examinations are normal. The abdomen is soft and nondistended with normoactive bowel sounds. There is tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium. Without rebound or guarding. No hepatosplenomegaly is appreciated. Which of the following additional factors would be expected given the most likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Abdominal pain that is worse after eating fatty foods

questions.solution:
This 16-year-old girl presents with new onset epigastric pain that worsens when she has not eaten and improves after eating. On physical exam, the abdomen is soft and nondistended with normoactive bowel sounds and there is tenderness to palpation in the epigastrium. These findings are concerning for peptic ulcer disease. Causes of peptic ulcer disease include nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use, steroid use, trauma, stress, and a family history of peptic ulcer disease.        

Patients with acute abdominal pain should be questioned regarding their stooling pattern to help determine the underlying etiology. Patients with Infectious gastroenteritis typically present with increased stooling frequency and diarrhea, whereas patients with constipation will present with decreased stooling frequency. It is also important to assess whether abdominal pain is related to eating. Pain from pancreatitis and cholecystitis often worsens after eating, whereas the pain from peptic ulcer disease improves after eating. Genitourinary illnesses such as urinary tract infections, urolithiasis, and ovarian cysts are not affected by eating and typically are not related to changes in stooling habits. These illnesses may present with dysuria, costovertebral tenderness, and unilateral lower abdominal pain with costovertebral tenderness, respectively.   

Option Analysis

✅ Recurrent use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID)  :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Stooling once per week:
Incorrect: A history of stooling once per week is diagnostic of constipation. Although constipation can cause abdominal pain, this patient’s history of epigastric pain that improves with eating is more consistent with peptic ulcer disease. Peptic ulcer disease is associated with recurrent use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID). 
❌ Abdominal pain that is worse after eating fatty foods:
Incorrect: A history of abdominal pain that is worse after eating fatty foods is associated with cholecystitis. This patient’s abdominal pain is in the epigastric region and not in the upper right quadrant, and it improves with eating, suggesting peptic ulcer disease. Peptic ulcer disease is associated with recurrent use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID). 
❌ Obesity:
Incorrect: Obesity is associated with cholecystitis. This patient’s abdominal pain and tenderness is in the epigastric region and not in the upper right quadrant and improves with eating, which is more consistent with peptic ulcer disease. Peptic ulcer disease is associated with recurrent use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID). Cholecystitis is rarely seen in pediatric patients.  
❌ Recent travel:
Incorrect: a history of recent travel in a patient with abdominal pain should raise suspicion for an infectious process such as acute gastroenteritis. However, this patient does not have a history of vomiting or diarrhea, and the findings are more consistent with peptic ulcer disease.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a 4-week history of intermittent abdominal pain localized to the epigastric region. The pain is described as a burning sensation that worsens at night and is partially relieved by eating. The parents note that the child has been less active recently and has occasionally experienced nausea but without vomiting or weight loss. The parents also mention that the child has experienced growing pains over the past several months. Vitals are within normal limits. On examination, the patient appears pale, and abdominal palpation reveals mild tenderness in the epigastric region without rebound or guarding. Cardiopulmonary examination is normal. Considering the most likely diagnosis, which of the following additional features is most likely to be present in this patient’s history?

choices.text: Frequent antibiotic use for recurrent ear infections

questions.solution:
This child’s symptoms are consistent with peptic ulcer disease (PUD), including epigastric pain that worsens at night and improves with food. This patient also has ongoing growing pains. Frequent use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) is a common cause of gastric mucosal injury and PUD.

In a pediatric patient with PUD, the history often includes chronic or intermittent epigastric pain described as burning, gnawing, or cramping in nature, worsening at night or between meals and relief after eating. Nausea, early satiety, bloating, or less commonly, vomiting, may also be reported. A history of gastrointestinal bleeding, such as hematemesis (vomiting blood) or melena (black, tarry stools), indicates a more severe presentation. Risk factors include regular use of NSAIDs or corticosteroids, severe physiologic stress (e.g., burns, severe trauma), a family history of PUD, or Helicobacter pylori infection. On physical examination, findings may include epigastric tenderness without rebound or guarding and pallor if there is significant anemia due to blood loss.

Option Analysis

❌ Frequent antibiotic use for recurrent ear infections:
Incorrect: While frequent antibiotic use may lead to gastrointestinal disturbances such as diarrhea, it is not associated with the development of peptic ulcer disease (PUD).
✅ Daily nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) use:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent streptococcal throat infection:
Incorrect: Streptococcal infections do not contribute to the development of peptic ulcer disease (PUD). This history would be relevant if the patient presented with symptoms of acute rheumatic fever or post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis.
❌ Consumption of a high-fat diet:
Incorrect: A high-fat diet may exacerbate symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) but does not cause peptic ulcer disease (PUD). This history would be pertinent in a child with regurgitation or heartburn suggestive of GERD.
❌ History of food allergies:
Incorrect: Food allergies typically cause acute or recurrent symptoms like vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain associated with specific dietary triggers, not chronic epigastric pain. This history would be relevant in a child with suspected eosinophilic esophagitis, food protein-induced enterocolitis syndrome, or an IgE-mediated food allergy.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presents to clinic with her parents for follow-up of a four-month history of burning chest pain and sour-tasting regurgitation. Symptoms begin mostly after meals and worsen when lying down or at night. The patient reports nausea but has not had vomiting, dysphagia, weight loss, or hematemesis. There is no history of chronic medical conditions. Over-the-counter antacids have provided temporary relief. After a prior visit, the patient began avoiding acidic foods and caffeine and now sleeps in the left lateral decubitus position with pillows elevating the head. These changes have not alleviated the symptoms. Growth parameters are at the 50<sup>th</sup> percentile, and BMI is 22 kg/m² (85<sup>th</sup> percentile). Vital signs are normal. Physical examination is unremarkable, with no abdominal tenderness, organomegaly, or lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosing this patient?

choices.text: Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy for 4-8 weeks

questions.solution:
This 12-year-old patient presents with classic symptoms of gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), including indigestion, regurgitation, and symptoms that worsen when lying down. These symptoms have not improved with lifestyle modifications. There are no warning signs such as weight loss, dysphagia, hematemesis, or systemic illness. The best next step, which may be both diagnostic and therapeutic, is a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) trial.

In older children and adolescents with typical GERD symptoms and no alarm features, initial management includes lifestyle modifications. These may involve weight reduction if appropriate and avoidance of caffeine and acidic foods. If relevant, alcohol and smoking cessation should be encouraged. Head-of-bed elevation and sleeping in the left lateral decubitus position may also help reduce symptoms.

If symptoms improve with lifestyle changes, this approach can be continued. If symptoms persist, an empiric trial of a PPI (e.g., omeprazole, lansoprazole) for 4 to 8 weeks is appropriate. A positive response supports the diagnosis of GERD. If symptoms continue despite PPI therapy, further evaluation (e.g., esophageal pH monitoring or esophagogastroduodenoscopy) should be pursued, with referral to a pediatric gastroenterologist as indicated.

Option Analysis

❌ Upper gastrointestinal (GI) series:
Incorrect: An upper GI series is useful for evaluating structural abnormalities, such as malrotation or strictures, but has limited utility in diagnosing gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). It is not indicated in patients with typical GERD symptoms unless alarm features are present.
✅ Proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy for 4-8 weeks:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ 24-hour esophageal pH monitoring:
Incorrect: Esophageal pH monitoring is typically reserved for cases with persistent or atypical symptoms despite an adequate trial of PPI therapy, or when the diagnosis remains uncertain.
❌ Esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) with biopsy:
Incorrect: EGD is indicated when alarm symptoms such as dysphagia, weight loss, hematemesis, or anemia are present, or when symptoms persist despite PPI treatment. It is not routinely recommended for initial evaluation of typical gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) symptoms.
❌ Abdominal ultrasonography:
Incorrect: While an abdominal ultrasound may be used in older children for other abdominal concerns such as suspected appendicitis or biliary disease, it is not appropriate in a patient with isolated, classic gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) symptoms without alarm features.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents with hematemesis and severe epigastric pain for the past 10 hours. The child had been experiencing intermittent abdominal pain and occasional nausea for the past two weeks, but medical attention was not sought. Earlier today, a large amount of blood was noted in the vomitus, prompting the parents to seek care. The child has no significant past medical history. The only medication taken is ibuprofen for a sprained ankle that occurred 10 days ago. Temperature is 36.7°C (98.1°F), heart rate is 150/min, blood pressure is 70/40 mmHg, respiratory rate is 26/min, and oxygen saturation is 99% on room air. The child appears pale and lethargic. Abdominal examination reveals tenderness localized to the epigastric region without rebound or guarding. The abdomen is soft. Tachycardia and a 2/6 flow murmur are appreciated at the left sternal border. Capillary refill is three seconds. What is the most appropriate initial management?

choices.text: Intravenous fluids (IV) and intravenous proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy

questions.solution:
This 7-year-old boy presents with life-threatening upper gastrointestinal bleeding, likely secondary to nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID)-induced gastric mucosal injury. The presence of hematemesis, hypotension, tachycardia, delayed capillary refill, and lethargy confirms hypovolemic shock. Initial management focuses on stabilizing the patient through fluid resuscitation with isotonic crystalloid fluids and intravenous proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy to reduce gastric acid secretion, stabilize the clot, and decrease the risk of rebleeding.  

The ABCDE approach for an unstable patient involves first addressing the Airway by ensuring it is patent with no signs of obstruction from hematemesis and monitoring for aspiration risk. Breathing is assessed, and supplemental oxygen can be provided if needed. Circulation should address any hemodynamic compromise. IV access should be obtained, and fluid resuscitation with crystalloids is used to restore perfusion. Blood transfusion may be required for severe anemia or persistent shock despite adequate fluid administration. Continuous monitoring of vital signs is essential. After stabilization, esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) should be performed to identify and control the bleeding source, using techniques such as thermal coagulation, mechanical clipping, or injection therapy.

Option Analysis

❌ Emergent esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD):
Incorrect: While EGD is essential for managing upper gastrointestinal bleeding, it is not the first step in an unstable patient. This child is in hypovolemic shock, as indicated by hypotension, tachycardia, delayed capillary refill, and lethargy. An attempt at stabilization with IV fluids and PPI therapy must be initiated before performing EGD.  
✅ Intravenous fluids (IV) and intravenous proton pump inhibitor (PPI) therapy:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Surgery consult for immediate laparotomy:
Incorrect: Surgical intervention is generally reserved for cases where endoscopic therapy fails or if there is evidence of perforation (e.g., rigid, diffusely tender abdomen). This patient needs stabilization followed by esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) as the first steps in management.
❌ Antiemetics and oral rehydration:
Incorrect: This approach is inappropriate for a patient with significant upper gastrointestinal bleeding and hemodynamic instability. Oral rehydration cannot restore the intravascular volume effectively in this setting, and antiemetics alone do not address the underlying pathology. This patient needs stabilization followed by esophagogastroduodenoscopy (EGD) as the first steps in management.
❌ Urea breath test:
Incorrect: While testing for Helicobacter pylori is relevant in the evaluation of peptic ulcer disease, it is not appropriate in an unstable patient. Immediate stabilization with IV fluids and management of active bleeding take precedence.

questions.text: A 4-week-old newborn boy is being evaluated by a pediatrician. The parents report that the infant has become increasingly fussy over the past two weeks and has been refusing to feed. The parents also note frequent regurgitation and back arching during feeds. The infant has not experienced any sustained episodes of increased work of breathing. Latch, suck, and swallow are intact, and the infant is formula-fed. Birth occurred at 37.5 weeks gestation via uncomplicated vaginal delivery. The prenatal course was unremarkable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Weight gain has been suboptimal. Physical examination reveals a well-appearing newborn in no acute distress. No craniofacial anomalies are noted. Cardiopulmonary and abdominal examinations are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This 4-week-old newborn infant presents with poor feeding, frequent regurgitation, inadequate weight gain, and arching of the back during feeds. Notably, the infant demonstrates an intact ability to latch, suck, and swallow, which helps narrow the differential diagnosis. Among the options provided, the clinical picture is most consistent with gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), a common and generally benign condition in infants. Initial management is conservative and includes keeping the infant upright during feeds and offering thickened formula. A trial of a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) may be considered if symptoms are severe or refractory.        

When evaluating poor feeding in infants, assessment should begin with the presence or absence of craniofacial anomalies. Conditions such as cleft lip or palate and micrognathia (i.e. a small mandible) often present with visible abnormalities that may impair feeding.        

In infants without craniofacial anomalies, the next step is to assess feeding mechanics, including the ability to latch, suck, and swallow. Inability to latch may suggest ankyloglossia, which is characterized by a restrictive lingual or upper lip frenulum. If swallowing is impaired despite normal oral anatomy, consider structural abnormalities that may not be apparent on physical exam, such as choanal atresia, esophageal atresia, or laryngomalacia. Differentiating between these conditions relies on a combination of clinical history and diagnostic tools such as imaging or endoscopic evaluation, including X-ray, computed tomography (CT), bronchoscopy, endoscopy, or laryngoscopy.   

Option Analysis

✅ Gastroesophageal reflux disease:
Correct: See Main Explanation 
❌ Choanal atresia:
Incorrect: Choanal atresia typically presents in the immediate neonatal period with cyclical cyanosis that improves with crying. Physical examination often reveals nasal obstruction. 
❌ Laryngomalacia:
Incorrect: Laryngomalacia presents with inspiratory stridor that worsens during feeding, agitation, or crying. Although regurgitation may coexist, stridor is a key feature and is not seen in this case.  
❌ Esophageal atresia:
Incorrect: Esophageal atresia presents shortly after birth with excessive drooling, coughing, and cyanosis during feeding. 
❌ Ankyloglossia:
Incorrect: Ankyloglossia is associated with difficulty latching, particularly during breastfeeding. Examination generally reveals a restrictive lingual frenulum, which is not present here.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after an episode of hematemesis. The patient was watching television when he felt nauseated and produced bright-red vomitus. Past medical history is notable for an ankle sprain, for which he is currently taking aspirin, and Helicobacter pylori infection, which was successfully treated 7 months ago. The patient consumes 4-6 beers per week and does not use tobacco products. His vitals are within normal limits. Endoscopy is performed and examination of the stomach reveals a protruding 2.5-mm arteriole that has eroded the overlying mucosa. There is active spurting of blood from the vessel. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a Dieulafoy lesion, which is a rare gastrointestinal (GI) condition characterized by an unusually dilated arteriole that erodes the overlying mucosa and is susceptible to bleeding from minor mucosal trauma. Dieulafoy lesions are most often located in the proximal stomach along the lesser curvature.  

The etiology of Dieulafoy lesion is unknown. However, individuals with comorbidities (e.g., cardiopulmonary dysfunction, chronic renal failure) and those taking medications that increase bleeding risk (e.g., aspirin, warfarin) have higher chances of developing Dieulafoy lesions.  

Patients with Dieulafoy lesions may experience signs of upper GI bleeding, including hematemesis, melena, and hematochezia. Endoscopy can be used to diagnose the condition and to perform epinephrine injections, thermocoagulation, and place hemostatic clips to treat it.  

 

Option Analysis

❌ Administration of intravenous octreotide:
Incorrect: Octreotide can stop active bleeding from ruptured esophageal varices. However, this patient has no history of portal hypertension. As a result, it would be unlikely for portacaval anastomoses to cause esophageal vein dilation in this patient.   
❌ Discontinuation of aspirin:
Incorrect: Aspirin may have contributed to this patient’s upper gastrointestinal tract bleed. Nonetheless, this patient is actively bleeding, and the next best step in management should involve trying to achieve hemostasis.  
❌ Surgical gastrectomy:
Incorrect: This patient has a Dieulafoy lesion, which is an unusually dilated arteriole that erodes the overlying mucosa and starts bleeding. Historically, surgical gastrectomy was used in the management of bleeding from Dieulafoy lesions. However, recent advances in endoscopy have made safer and less invasive interventions possible.  
✅ Thermal coagulation of bleeding site:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Initiation of propranolol therapy:
Incorrect: Beta-blockers are used for prophylaxis against variceal bleeds. However, this patient has a dilated arteriole in the stomach that has eroded overlying mucosa. This is more consistent with the presentation of a Dieulafoy lesion. Beta-blockers are not used in the prophylaxis or acute management of Dieulafoy lesion bleeding.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man is brought to the emergency room because of an episode of hematemesis, which occurred an hour ago. Medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder and liver cirrhosis. Review of the electronic medical record shows that the patient had undergone upper endoscopy a year ago for evaluation of dysphagia and was diagnosed with esophageal varices. He was subsequently started on propranolol. Examination of the patient’s eyes reveals scleral icterus. Abdominal exam is notable for hepatomegaly and ascites. Intravenous fluids are administered, endoscopic band ligation is performed, and hemostasis is achieved. Ten-days later, however, the patient has another episode of hematemesis. Which of the following interventions will be most useful in preventing future gastrointestinal tract bleeding in this patient?

choices.text: Placement of transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt

questions.solution:
This patient has recurrent variceal bleeding, which is defined as bleeding that occurs more than 120 hours after the first episode of hemorrhage, provided that hemostasis was initially achieved. As a result, transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting (TIPS) is indicated to prevent future variceal rebleeding. The procedure involves creating an artificial shunt between the inflowing portal vein and outflowing hepatic vein, thereby reducing portal resistance and hypertension. TIPS is also indicated for patients with first time variceal bleeding that is refractory to treatment by medications (e.g. octreotide) and endoscopic band ligation.    

In either of the aforementioned scenarios, a balloon tamponade is temporarily placed in the esophagus to stop bleeding until TIPS can be performed.



Option Analysis

❌ Long-term octreotide therapy:
Incorrect: Octreotide can be used to stop acute variceal bleeding and should be continued for 3-5 days. However, its efficacy as secondary prophylaxis has not been demonstrated. Moreover, the patient has had variceal rebleeding, defined as a bleeding episode occurring 120 hours or more after the initial episode. This is an indication for transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting.  
❌ Long-term nadolol therapy :
Incorrect: Beta-blockers, such as propranolol and nadolol, can be used for prophylaxis against variceal bleeding. This patient was previously started on propranolol but nonetheless had variceal bleeding. As a result, switching to nadolol will most likely not help prevent future episodes of variceal bleeding. 
❌ Perform esophageal transection:
Incorrect: The Sugiura procedure involves removing and transecting the blood vessels that supply the esophagus and upper portion of the stomach. It can be used to treat esophageal variceal bleeding that is refractory to other interventions. However, the procedure has high mortality rates. As a result, transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting is preferred over surgical intervention. 
✅ Placement of transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Initiation of lactulose therapy:
Incorrect: Patients with gastrointestinal bleeding are at increased risk of developing hepatic encephalopathy. This is because hemoglobin in the gastrointestinal tract can be broken down into ammonia and absorbed into the bloodstream. Lactulose traps ammonia in the colon and prevents absorption. However, it would not reduce the risk of future variceal rebleeding.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after vomiting bright red blood. The patient was at home watching television when he suddenly felt nauseous and vomited. He denies any recent trauma. Examination of the eye reveals scleral icterus. Abdominal exam reveals the presence of ascites and hepatomegaly. An upper endoscopy is performed and confirms the presence of dilated veins in the distal esophagus which have ruptured. Which of the following is most likely present in this patient’s medical history?
questions.solution:
Esophageal varices are dilated submucosal veins in the lower third of the esophagus. They are most often caused by portal hypertension, which may be due to liver cirrhosis caused by viral hepatitis or chronic alcohol use. Portal hypertension leads to increased pressure within the small vessels that connect the portal circulation with the systemic circulation. Over time, these small vessels dilate and blood is shunted through these anastomoses, which have lower resistance than the cirrhotic liver. In particular, dilation of the left gastric and azygos veins contributes to the development of esophageal varices.    

If esophageal varices become perforated and rupture, such as when eating hard foods or during vomiting, patients can develop life-threatening hematemesis. Variceal bleeding has a mortality rate of 10-20%. 

Option Analysis

❌ Long-term aspirin use:
Incorrect: Aspirin impairs platelet function and increases the risk of bleeding, thus predisposing patients to gastrointestinal tract bleeding. However, it would be atypical for aspirin to cause portal hypertension and the subsequent formation of esophageal varices. 
✅ Hepatitis C infection :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hepatitis A infection:
Incorrect: Hepatitis A is a virus that can cause acute hepatitis, which can manifest with jaundice, right upper quadrant pain, and hepatomegaly. However, most infections self-resolve, and patients are unlikely to develop chronic liver damage or portal hypertension from the infection. 
❌ Bisphosphonate overuse:
Incorrect: Bisphosphonates can lead to pill-induced esophageal ulcers and potentially esophageal perforation. However, this patient’s endoscopic findings of dilated and ruptured veins is more consistent with esophageal varices, which arise secondary to portal hypertension and subsequent shunting of blood between the left gastric and azygos veins. 
❌ Helicobacter pylori infection:
Incorrect: Infection by Helicobacter pylori (H. pylori) can lead to peptic ulcers, which can cause upper gastrointestinal tract bleeding. However, H. pylori would not lead to portal hypertension or the subsequent development of esophageal varices.

questions.text: A 52-year-old man is brought to the emergency department after complaining of excruciating chest pain that radiates to the back. He also reports shortness of breath and pain with swallowing. The symptoms began 30 minutes ago, after the patient consumed a large quantity of alcohol and had several episodes of forceful vomiting. Past medical history is notable for hypertension, alcohol use disorder, and liver cirrhosis. His temperature is 37.2°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 142/78 mmHg, and pulse is 75/min. Physical exam shows crepitus on palpation of the upper chest wall. Abdominal exam is notable for hepatosplenomegaly. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Order computed tomography of the chest

questions.solution:
This patient has Boerhaave syndrome, which is a transmural rupture of the distal esophagus secondary to increases in intraesophageal pressure. Vomiting is the most common cause of Boerhaave syndrome. The condition can manifest with chest pain, vomiting, and subcutaneous emphysema, which can cause crackles to be heard on palpation of the skin (crepitus).  

Diagnosis is made using x-ray, which will show air that has escaped the esophagus, followed by a contrast esophagram, which will confirm the diagnosis, as well as determine the location and size of the perforation. A CT scan can be used in cases when a contrast esophagram cannot be performed (e.g. if a patient is hemodynamically unstable or uncooperative) or if the results come back inconclusive.  

Management varies depending on the severity of the perforation. Patients with small ruptures can be treated with volume replacement, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and avoidance of all oral intake. In contrast, patients with large perforations, fever, sepsis, pneumomediastinum or pneumothorax will require surgical intervention.   

Option Analysis

❌ Perform diagnostic endoscopy:
Incorrect: This patient likely has Boerhaave syndrome, which is a rupture of the distal esophagus due to sudden increases in esophageal pressure. The work-up process involves a chest x-ray followed by esophagram to confirm the diagnosis. Endoscopy is not used in the work-up of Boerhaave syndrome, since the procedure can lead to further esophageal damage.  
❌ Administration of octreotide:
Incorrect: Octreotide can be used to treat acute variceal bleeding. The patient’s history of alcohol use disorder and liver cirrhosis increase his risk of developing esophageal varices. However, it would be atypical for a variceal bleeding to cause crepitus on palpation, which suggests subcutaneous emphysema.  
❌ Immediate surgical repair:
Incorrect: Surgical intervention may be needed to close the ruptured esophageal segment. However, a chest x-ray or esophagram should be ordered first to confirm the diagnosis, as well as to assess the location and size of the perforation.  
❌ Order computed tomography of the chest  :
Incorrect: This patient’s presentation raises concerns for Boerhaave syndrome. A CT scan is an alternative work-up approach for patients who are hemodynamically unstable or have inconclusive esophagram results. In contrast, this patient is hemodynamically stable and an esophagram should be attempted first.   
✅ Perform contrast esophagram:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room after vomiting bright red blood several times over the past hour. The patient was at home reading a book when she suddenly felt nauseous and vomited. Past medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 95/66 mmHg, and pulse is 110/min. Examination of the eyes reveals scleral icterus. Abdominal exam reveals hepatomegaly. Two peripheral intravenous catheters are placed, and the patient is started on a normal saline infusion. Repeat of the vitals reveals a blood pressure of 120/77 mmHg, and pulse of 86/min. Laboratory testing reveals a hemoglobin level of 9.2 g/dL. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Referral for transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting

questions.solution:
Esophageal varices are dilated submucosal veins in the lower third of the esophagus. They are most often caused by portal hypertension, which may be due to liver cirrhosis brought about by viral hepatitis or chronic alcohol use. Patients with esophageal varices can have life-threatening hematemesis if the varices rupture. This complication may occur when eating hard food or during vomiting.  

The first step in management is to place at least two large-bore intravenous catheters. Afterwards, intravenous fluids, octreotide, and broad-spectrum antibiotics can be administered. Octreotide induces splanchnic vasoconstriction, decreases portal blood flow, and ultimately reduces the amount of blood lost via the varices. Broad spectrum antibiotics, such as ceftriaxone, are administered to prevent infection. Antibiotic administration is particularly important in patients with liver cirrhosis, as they are at increased risk of developing spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Patients should also be made NPO.  

After the patient is hemodynamically stable, endoscopy can be performed to confirm the diagnosis and ligate the bleeding site.



Option Analysis

❌ Initiation of propranolol therapy:
Incorrect: Propranolol can be used for bleeding prophylaxis in patients with esophageal varices. However, this patient has active bleeding, as suggested by the bright red emesis, tachycardia, and borderline hypotension. Propranolol is ineffective at stopping active variceal bleeding. 
❌ Perform upper gastrointestinal endoscopy :
Incorrect: This patient likely has variceal bleeding. The first step is to ensure the patient is hemodynamically stable. Next, medications such as octreotide and broad-spectrum antibiotics can be administered to reduce bleeding and prevent infection, respectively. Only then should an upper gastrointestinal endoscopy be performed to confirm the diagnosis and stop the bleeding.  
❌ Initiation of whole blood transfusion :
Incorrect: Although this patient has an active gastrointestinal tract bleed, her hemoglobin level is not low enough to warrant a transfusion. Generally, a transfusion is indicated only when a patient’s hemoglobin level falls below 7 g/dL. 
❌ Referral for transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting:
Incorrect: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting (TIPS) is a procedure that can be performed on patients with recurring or treatment-resistant variceal bleeding secondary to portal hypertension. In contrast, this patient has no history of prior bleeding. Moreover, medications (e.g. octreotide) and endoscopic procedures (e.g. band ligation) should be tried first before proceeding to TIPS.  
✅  Initiation of octreotide therapy :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of excruciating chest pain. The patient endorses shortness of breath and pain with swallowing. The symptoms began one-and-a-half hours ago, after the patient consumed large quantities of whiskey with friends and subsequently had several episodes of forceful vomiting. Past medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder, peptic ulcer disease, and hepatitis B infection. Three days ago, he underwent endoscopic evaluation for peptic ulcer disease. The patient’s temperature is 37.9°C (99.0°F), blood pressure is 112/68 mmHg, pulse is 110/min, and respirations are 25/min. Physical exam is notable for crepitus on palpation of the upper chest wall. Chest radiography reveals a widened mediastinum. Which of the following risk factors most likely contributed to the patient’s current symptoms?
questions.solution:
This patient has Boerhaave syndrome, which is transmural rupture of the distal esophagus secondary to increases in intraesophageal pressure. Vomiting is the most common cause of Boerhaave syndrome. Other potential causes include epileptic seizures, abdominal trauma, and childbirth, all of which can increase pressure within the esophagus. The condition can manifest with chest pain, vomiting, and subcutaneous emphysema, which can cause crackles to be heard on palpation of the skin.  

One commonly tested concept is the difference between Boerhaave syndrome and a Mallory-Weiss tear. Boerhaave syndrome is much more severe, and since it involves a full-thickness tear, air can escape into the mediastinum causing crepitus and Hammond sign (precordial crackles that occur synchronously with the heartbeat). In contrast, Mallory-Weiss syndrome causes only a partial thickness tear, so no air is able to escape the esophagus. 

Option Analysis

❌ Peptic ulcer disease :
Incorrect: An untreated gastric ulcer may perforate, allowing air and gastric contents to enter the abdominal cavity. This would cause pneumoperitoneum, and an x-ray would reveal subdiaphragmatic free air. In contrast, it would be atypical for a perforated gastric ulcer to cause mediastinal widening.  
❌ Alcohol use disorder :
Incorrect: Excess alcohol use would not directly contribute to the development of esophageal perforation. However, alcohol overconsumption may lead to repeated episodes of forceful emesis, which can in turn cause esophageal perforation.  
❌ Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy:
Incorrect: It is possible for an endoscope to perforate the esophagus. This would account for the patient’s chest pain, crepitus, and widened mediastinum. However, the endoscopic procedure was performed three days ago. It would be unusual for an esophageal perforation to first become symptomatic several days later. 
✅ Repeated episodes of emesis:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Hepatitis B infection :
Incorrect: Hepatitis B infection can lead to liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension. This can predispose patients to developing esophageal varices. However, this patient’s presentation of chest pain and crepitus after several episodes of forceful emesis is more consistent with Boerhaave syndrome. Hepatitis B infection is not a risk factor for developing this condition.

questions.text: A 63-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after an episode of hematemesis. The patient was at home reading a book when he felt nauseous and produced bright-red emesis. Past medical history is notable for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He is currently taking propranolol and atorvastatin. The patient consumes 1-2 beers per week and has a 40-pack-year smoking history. Upon arrival, blood pressure is 140/85 mmHg and pulse is 85/min. Physical exam reveals a nontender and nondistended abdomen with no hepatomegaly. Endoscopy is performed, and visualization of the stomach reveals a protruding 2.7-mm arteriole that has eroded the overlying mucosa. There is active spurting of blood from the vessel. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Placement of transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt
Endoscopic thermal coagulation of bleeding site

questions.solution:
This patient has a Dieulafoy lesion, which is a rare condition characterized by an unusually dilated arteriole that erodes the overlying mucosa and starts bleeding. Dieulafoy lesions are most often located in the proximal stomach along the lesser curvature.    

The etiology of Dieulafoy lesions is unknown. However, individuals with comorbidities (e.g., cardiopulmonary dysfunction, chronic renal failure) and those taking medications that increase bleeding risk (e.g., aspirin, warfarin) have higher chances of developing Dieulafoy lesions. Patients with Dieulafoy lesions may experience hematemesis, melena, and hematochezia.    

Patients with bleeding from a Dieulafoy lesion should have at least two large-bore intravenous catheters. Patients should also be started on intravenous fluids and a proton pump inhibitor (PPI) and be made NPO (nothing by mouth).  

Once hemodynamic stability has been achieved, upper gastrointestinal endoscopy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and stop the bleeding. Hemostasis can be achieved by epinephrine injections along with thermocoagulation or hemostatic clip placement.    

In cases wherein endoscopy cannot stop the bleeding, a subtotal gastrectomy may be necessary.  

Option Analysis

❌ Administration of intravenous octreotide :
Incorrect: Octreotide can help reduce bleeding from ruptured esophageal varices. However, this patient has no signs of liver cirrhosis or portal hypertension. As a result, it is unlikely that portacaval shunting and esophageal vein dilation would have developed in this patient. 
❌ Placement of transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt  :
Incorrect: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting (TIPS) involves creating an artificial shunt between the inflowing portal vein and outflowing hepatic vein. This reduces portal hypertension. TIPS can treat recurrent variceal bleeding or first-time variceal bleeding that is refractory to medical or endoscopic management. However, TIPS is not effective in treating bleeding from a Dieulafoy lesion.  
❌ Surgical gastrectomy :
Incorrect: This patient has a Dieulafoy lesion, which is an unusually dilated arteriole that erodes the overlying mucosa and starts bleeding. Historically, surgical gastrectomy was used to treat bleeding from Dieulafoy lesions. However, recent advances in endoscopy have made safer and less invasive interventions available. 
❌ Initiation of ampicillin-sulbactam therapy:
Incorrect: Ampicillin-sulbactam is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that provides coverage against aerobic and anaerobic pathogens. It can be administered to patients with gastrointestinal tract perforation (e.g., esophageal rupture, perforated gastric ulcer) to reduce infection risk. However, this patient’s endoscopic findings are more consistent with that of a Dieulafoy lesion. Patients with bleeding from a Dieulafoy lesion would not need antibiotic therapy. 
✅ Endoscopic thermal coagulation of bleeding site:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after an episode of hematemesis. The patient spent last night at a bar drinking with his colleagues. After leaving the bar, he vomited four times, and during the last episode, he noticed bright-red blood mixed with the vomitus. Past medical history is notable for hyperlipidemia and peripheral artery disease, for which he is taking atorvastatin and aspirin. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.9°F), blood pressure is 130/74 mmHg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 17/min. During the physical exam, the patient is anxious but not in acute distress. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. Laboratory testing yields the results shown below. Which of the following additional findings will most likely develop in this patient?

Laboratory Value   Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)    Result (U.S. conventional units)  Results (SI units)  
 Sodium  142 mg/dL  142 mmol/L 
 Potassium  3.8 mg/dL  3.8 mmol/L 
 Chloride  100 mg/dL  100 mmol/L 
 Bicarbonate  35 mg/dL  35 mmol/L

choices.text: Passage of bright-red blood from the anus
Presence of multiple spider angioma on the body

questions.solution:
This patient likely has a Mallory-Weiss tear, which is a partial-thickness laceration of the esophageal mucosa secondary to forceful and repeated vomiting. Mallory-Weiss tears can lead to gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding.    

GI bleeding can be divided into upper and lower bleeding. Upper GI bleeding arises above the ligament of Treitz (also termed suspensory ligament of the duodenum) and includes bleeding from the esophagus, stomach, and duodenum. Symptoms include hematemesis (vomiting of fresh red blood), ‘coffee ground’ vomitus (vomiting of blood that has been oxidized by stomach acids), and melena (black and tarry stools). In rare cases, if an upper GI lesion is bleeding briskly, blood may pass through the remainder of the GI tract too quickly to be oxidized, in which case fresh blood may pass from the anus. However, it would be highly unusual for a Mallory-Weis tear to bleed so severely, particularly in this patient with stable vital signs.    

In contrast, lower GI bleeding arises below the ligament of Treitz and includes bleeding from the small intestine distal to the duodenum, large intestines, rectum, and anus. Typical presentation includes hematochezia (fresh blood passing through the anus).    

If individuals lose significant quantities of blood via GI bleeding, they can develop anemia. 

Option Analysis

✅ Black tarry stools:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Passage of bright-red blood from the anus:
Incorrect: Patients with lower gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding may notice bright-red blood mixed with their stool. In contrast, this patient most likely has a Mallory-Weiss tear, which is an upper GI bleed caused by forceful and repeated vomiting. Blood from an upper GI bleed will have oxidized by the time it is expelled and appear dark in color. 
❌ Foul-smelling oily stools:
Incorrect: Foul-smelling and oily stools may be observed in patients with fat malabsorption. This can be due to various conditions, including pancreatic insufficiency, inflammatory bowel disease, and Giardia infection. However, it would be atypical for a patient to develop this symptom after an episode of GI bleeding. 
❌ Presence of multiple spider angioma on the body:
Incorrect: Patients with cirrhosis can develop multiple spider angiomas on their bodies, due to the damaged liver’s inability to metabolize estrogen. Hyperestrogenism in turn causes vasodilation. However, this patient lacks symptoms suggestive of liver cirrhosis, such as jaundice, ascites, or hepatomegaly. 
❌ Sloughed mucosa mixed with stool:
Incorrect: This describes currant jelly stools, which occur when sloughed mucosa, blood, and mucus are mixed with the stool. This phenomenon is often found in patients with intestinal ischemia or intussusception, both of which can lead to lower GI bleeding. In contrast, this patient has upper GI bleeding. Blood from an upper GI bleed will have oxidized by the time it is expelled with feces.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man is brought to the emergency room for hematemesis that occurred an hour ago. Earlier in the evening, the patient had consumed large quantities of vodka at a bar and subsequently vomited four times. The last episode of vomiting resulted in a bright red emesis. At arrival, temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), blood pressure is 116/75 mmHg, and pulse is 68/min. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are noncontributory. While in the emergency room, the patient has another episode of hematemesis. Two large-bore peripheral catheters are placed, and the patient is stated on intravenous fluids and pantoprazole. Which of the following interventions is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has a Mallory-Weiss tear, also termed gastro-esophageal laceration syndrome, which manifests as a longitudinal, partial-thickness tear of the gastroesophageal junction mucosa. The condition most often occurs due to forceful vomiting, which increases intra-abdominal pressure.      

Patients with Mallory-Weiss tears, similar to those with other upper gastrointestinal bleeds, should get at least two large-bore intravenous catheters. Afterwards they should be started on intravenous fluids and a proton pump inhibitor (PPI).    

For patients whose bleeding has spontaneously stopped, no additional intervention is required. For those with active bleeding, upper gastrointestinal endoscopy should be performed to confirm the diagnosis and achieve hemostasis. This can be achieved via thermal coagulation, hemoclips, or band ligation. 

Option Analysis

❌ Chest radiograph:
Incorrect: A chest radiograph is useful in the work-up of patients with esophageal perforation. Imaging may show mediastinal widening and pneumomediastinum, due to free air accumulation. Esophageal perforation will cause dyspnea, chest pain, crepitus on palpation, and crackles on auscultation. In contrast, this patient has none of the aforementioned symptoms. 
❌ Esophageal barium swallow:
Incorrect: An esophageal barium swallow study can reveal mucosal lacerations. However, upper gastrointestinal (GI) endoscopy is more accurate and is necessary to definitively diagnose a patient with a Mallory-Weiss tear. Moreover, endoscopy can also be used to achieve hemostasis. 
✅ Upper gastrointestinal endoscopy:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Computed tomography of the chest:
Incorrect: This patient has upper gastrointestinal bleeding after heavy drinking and vomiting, which is concerning for a Mallory-Weiss tear. The absence of crepitus makes full-thickness esophageal perforation unlikely. Since Mallory-Weiss tears are partial-thickness lacerations, they will most likely be radiographically occult and missed on a CT scan. 
❌ Blood alcohol level :
Incorrect: This patient has been consuming large quantities of alcohol and will have an elevated blood alcohol level. However, this test does not help differentiate between the different potential sources of GI bleeding (e.g., Mallory-Weiss syndrome, Boerhaave syndrome, gastric ulcer, etc.), and it is therefore not useful in management.

questions.text:
A 47-year-old woman is brought to the emergency room after vomiting bright red blood several times over the past hour. She denies any recent trauma. Past medical history is notable for alcohol use disorder and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.9°C (100.2°F), blood pressure is 95/68 mmHg, and pulse is 107/min. Examination of the eyes reveals scleral icterus. Abdominal exam reveals hepatomegaly and the following shown below. Two peripheral intravenous catheters are placed, and a normal saline infusion is started. Repeat vitals are obtained, revealing a blood pressure of 120/77 mmHg, and pulse of 83/min. Octreotide and ceftriaxone therapy are also initiated. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?



Image reproduced from Wikimedia Commons

choices.text: Placement of a central venous catheter
Referral for transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting

questions.solution:
This patient has hematemesis in the setting of liver cirrhosis and portal hypertension (as evidenced by exam findings of scleral icterus, ascites, and hepatomegaly, in the setting of alcohol use disorder); this presentation is highly concerning for an esophageal variceal bleed. Variceal bleeding can cause life-threatening hematemesis, with mortality rates between 10-20%.    

The first step in management is to place at least two large-bore intravenous catheters. Afterwards, intravenous fluids, octreotide, and broad-spectrum antibiotics should be administered. Octreotide induces splanchnic vasoconstriction, decreases portal blood flow, and ultimately reduces the amount of blood that is lost via the varices. Broad spectrum antibiotics, such as ceftriaxone, are administered to prevent infection. Antibiotic administration is especially important in patients with liver cirrhosis, as they are at increased risk of developing spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. Patients should also be made NPO (nothing by mouth).  

Once the patient has been stabilized, the next step is to perform upper gastrointestinal tract endoscopy. This will help both confirm the diagnosis and ligate the bleeding source.  


Option Analysis

❌ Placement of a central venous catheter:
Incorrect: A central venous catheter is helpful in patients who require hemodynamic monitoring, require medications that cannot be given peripherally (e.g., vasopressors, chemotherapy), or have inadequate peripheral venous access. At present, this patient lacks any indications for central venous catheter placement. 
✅ Perform upper gastrointestinal endoscopy :
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Initiation of liver function testing:
Incorrect: This patient most likely has liver cirrhosis, as suggested by the scleral icterus, hepatomegaly, and abdominal ascites. Testing will reveal elevated liver enzymes. However, this patient has active bleeding and achieving hemostasis should be the top priority. 
❌ Referral for transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting:
Incorrect: Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunting (TIPS) is a procedure that can be performed on patients with recurring or treatment-resistant variceal bleeding arising secondary to portal hypertension. In contrast, this patient has no prior episodes of gastrointestinal bleeding. Hence, medications (e.g. octreotide) and endoscopic procedures (e.g. band ligation) should be tried first before proceeding to TIPS.  
❌ Initiation of propranolol therapy:
Incorrect: Propranolol can be used for secondary prophylaxis to reduce the risk of future bleeding from esophageal varices. However, this patient had an episode of active variceal bleeding an hour ago. Propranolol is not effective against active bleeds.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by his partner after multiple episodes of hematemesis. The patient is unresponsive and unable to provide a history. According to his partner, the patient had spent the evening at a bar where he consumed more than 10 shots of liquor. After leaving the bar, he vomited multiple times. There was bright-red blood mixed with the vomitus. While in the emergency department, the patient has two additional episodes of hematemesis. During the physical exam, the patient mumbles incoherently, is unable to follow commands, and tries to push away the examiner’s hands. Pupils are 3 centimeters bilaterally and reactive to light. Cardiac, pulmonary, and abdominal exams are non-contributory. Which of the following is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient has hematemesis in the setting of multiple episodes of vomiting, which is most consistent with a Mallory-Weiss tear. Mallory-Weiss tears are partial-thickness lacerations to the esophageal mucosa that occur secondary to forceful and repeated vomiting.  

In addition, this patient has an altered level of consciousness, which is a major risk factor for the aspiration of blood and gastric contents. As a result, the patient should undergo endotracheal intubation to prevent aspiration.



Option Analysis

❌ Order urine toxicology:
Incorrect: This patient has altered mental status. Substances, such as benzodiazepines and opiates, can potentially be the underlying cause and will show up on a urine toxicology study. However, this patient has active hematemesis and altered consciousness, which increases his risk of aspiration. As a result, the patient should be immediately intubated to prevent airway compromise. 
❌ Initiation of octreotide therapy  :
Incorrect: Octreotide can be used to reduce variceal bleeding, a condition that usually develops in patients with portal hypertension.
